The veggie options are particularly noteworthy, providing a satisfying selection for those who prefer lighter toppings. The service is consistently described as friendly and fast, with staff known for their attentiveness and passion for their work. Guests have also appreciated the cozy seating, which includes both indoor and outdoor options, perfect for enjoying a meal in nice weather. The pricing is considered quite reasonable, making it a fantastic choice for dinner or a casual lunch. With delightful service and mouthwatering pizza, many patrons express their eagerness to return for another enjoyable experience. Overall, Sol Pizza stands out as a must-visit spot for pizza lovers looking for quality and value.

formattedAddress: 635 Markham St, Toronto, ON M6G 2M1, Canada
editorialSummary: Traditional & gourmet stone-baked pizzas, with options like gluten-free crust & pesto sauce.
reviews: Pizzaville has garnered mixed reviews focused primarily on its pizza selections and customer service. The Bacon Spinach Artichoke pizza has been highlighted as a standout favorite, along with a large Hawaiian pizza that impressed a customer with both its flavor and the service received. However, there was disappointment with the wings, which were criticized for being dry and inadequately sauced, leaving a less than favorable impression. Despite this, many customers have praised the exceptional customer service, noting the staff's attentiveness and kindness, particularly in accommodating children. Cleanliness of the establishment also received commendation. Overall, while the pizzas, especially the Hawaiian and Bacon Spinach Artichoke, are recommended for a satisfying meal, potential diners may want to reconsider the wings based on recent experiences. This restaurant is a solid choice for pizza lovers looking for a casual dining experience.

formattedAddress: 1151 Davenport Rd, Toronto, ON M6H 2G4, Canada
reviews: This cozy pizzeria has quickly become a neighborhood favorite, offering an extensive menu that includes delicious pizzas, fresh salads, and satisfying sandwiches. Patrons rave about the pepperoni pizza, noting its perfect balance of cheese, crust, and toppings, particularly when enhanced with hot honey or chili oil. The beet and goat cheese salad has also received praise for its fresh ingredients and balanced flavors. Customers appreciate the airy yet crispy bread of the chicken sandwich, accompanied by perfectly juicy chicken and a sauce on the side. The friendly service adds to the inviting atmosphere, making it an ideal spot for a quick meal after events or a casual dinner with friends. Overall, this restaurant delivers exceptional food and a welcoming experience, making it highly recommended for anyone in the area.

formattedAddress: 40 University Ave Unit 7, Toronto, ON M5J 1T1, Canada
displayName: DoughBox Wood Fired Pizza & Pasta - Toronto (University)
reviews: This restaurant offers a fantastic dining experience with a focus on pizza and pasta. The highlight for many patrons is the thin crust pizza, praised for its perfect crunch and fresh ingredients, with favorites like the Wild Pepperoni and Twisted Club pizzas standing out. Guests appreciated the option to create their own pizza, reminiscent of MOD pizza, and enjoyed the delicious toppings available, including a vegan-friendly choice with five toppings. The wings, while tasty, received mixed reviews; some found them a bit soggy, although the garlic and buffalo sauces were commendable. Many reviewers were impressed by the atmosphere, describing it as minimalistic and rustic, with both indoor and outdoor seating options. The Carbonara pasta and kid-friendly pasta meal also received positive feedback, showcasing the restaurant's diverse menu. Overall, the service was highlighted as friendly and efficient, making it a great spot for lunch or dinner. Diners left satisfied and eager to return for more culinary delights.

formattedAddress: 997 Bay St., Toronto, ON M5S 3A6, Canada
editorialSummary: Relaxed chain restaurant for signature & build-your-own pizzas, plus sandwiches & salads.
reviews: This restaurant is renowned for its exceptional pizza and friendly service, making it a popular spot for both lunch and dinner. Diners appreciate the convenience of ordering pizza by the slice, allowing for a quick meal on the go, and many commend the staff for their warm greetings and attention to regulars. The lasagna, typically served with garlic bread, has also received positive feedback, with patrons recommending extra sauce for added flavor. Guests enjoy a relaxed atmosphere and the option to enjoy beer, which adds to the overall dining experience. A few reviews, however, highlight inconsistencies in the quality of the food, with some diners expressing disappointment over the scarcity of toppings and sauce on their pizza. Despite these criticisms, the cleanliness of the restaurant and the attentiveness of the staff contribute to its positive reputation. Overall, while many customers rave about the food and friendly vibe, some have noted room for improvement in portion sizes and quality.

formattedAddress: 253 Augusta Ave, Toronto, ON M5T 2L8, Canada
reviews: Pizzeria de Mario is a highly regarded late-night pizza spot in Kensington Market, with patrons raving about the quality of their offerings, particularly the Diavola and the traditional pepperoni slices. Many reviews highlight the incredible thin and crunchy texture of the pizza, with some claiming it evokes nostalgic memories of greater Montreal pizza. One customer appreciated the generous size and massive pepperoni on their slice, noting that it was a satisfying end to a late night. However, not all experiences were positive; a few diners found the pizza excessively salty, leading to disappointment with their order. The four-cheese pizza also received criticism for stale cheese. Despite these mixed reviews, the overall sentiment is that the restaurant is a solid choice for late-night takeout, especially if you call ahead to ensure availability. Friendly service and a welcoming atmosphere add to the restaurant's appeal, but diners seeking authentic Neapolitan pizza may want to approach with caution.

formattedAddress: 899 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6H 1L2, Canada
reviews: This cozy restaurant offers a unique blend of Middle Eastern and Italian cuisine, featuring dishes such as lamb Shawarma sandwiches, Muskhan, and a non-traditional Meat Habibi pizza. Diners rave about the balanced flavor profiles, although some find the honey cauliflower slightly too sweet. Guests commend the generous portions and fresh ingredients, with many opting for halal meat options. The mixed pizza comes highly recommended for its crisp crust and ample toppings, promising enough leftovers for future meals. For dessert, the baklava cheesecake garners rave reviews, touted as a superior offering compared to other well-known chains. Reservations are advised for groups, given the small but inviting atmosphere. With a variety of delicious mocktails like the Phony Negroni and Hibiscus refresher, this eatery provides a well-rounded dining experience. Overall, patrons express their eagerness to return and explore more dishes from the extensive menu.

formattedAddress: 603 Davenport Rd, Toronto, ON M5R 1L1, Canada
editorialSummary: Relaxed chain restaurant for signature & build-your-own pizzas, plus sandwiches & salads.
reviews: The restaurant experience seems to be a mix of decent food but disappointing service. Some reviewers found the custom pizzas enjoyable, while the ready-to-go slices lacked freshness. For brunch or casual dining, the gourmet pizza slices were appreciated, although some were frustrated by the lack of complimentary ketchup for their dipping sauces, especially after spending over $14. Unfortunately, one reviewer had a particularly negative experience with chicken wings and potato wedges, citing long wait times and poor food quality, describing the wings as dry and burned. Others noted that the cashiers could be rude, disorganized, and unwelcoming, which detracted from the overall experience. On a positive note, the restaurant appears to be sensitive to dietary restrictions as they have a good procedure for making vegan pizzas for those with severe dairy allergies. Additionally, food delivery was praised for its promptness, with deliveries arriving swiftly and drivers being friendly. Overall, while the food can be decent, the strange vibes and inconsistent service may discourage repeat visits.

formattedAddress: 193 Harbord St, Toronto, ON M5S 2R5, Canada
editorialSummary: Relaxed chain restaurant for signature & build-your-own pizzas, plus sandwiches & salads.
reviews: The restaurant is known for its pizzas, with customers generally praising the flavor and variety offered, including options like a vegan pizza featuring plant-based meat and a classic pepperoni and mushroom pie. Many reviews highlight the friendly staff, contributing to a positive dining experience. However, there are concerns regarding food safety, as one customer noted an unsanitary practice involving staff handling food after being outside without washing their hands. Additionally, a recurring issue is the inconsistency in pizza quality, with multiple reports of pizzas being burned to the point of being inedible, resulting in wasted meals. Some diners received pizzas delivered by services like Skip the Dishes and Uber Eats that were so poorly prepared they were deemed unfit for consumption. Despite the mixed reviews, the establishment is appreciated for its fresh toppings and excellent vegan options. Overall, while the restaurant has the potential for a great meal, the inconsistency in food quality and hygiene practices raises concerns among patrons.

formattedAddress: 189 Harbord St, Toronto, ON M5S 1H5, Canada
editorialSummary: Specializing in handcrafted pies, this corner spot is open late for eat-in, delivery & takeout.
reviews: The restaurant offers a variety of pizzas with some mixed reviews from patrons. One customer praised the taste of their pizza, describing it as one of the better options in the area, but faced a significant hygiene issue with multiple strands of hair found baked into the cheese. They appreciated the offer to replace the pizza but were disappointed that this happened in their meal. Another reviewer complimented the establishment for its traditional pies and the friendly service, highlighting their connection to the local community. While the price of $6 for a large slice was seen as a good value, some mentioned the atmosphere as a bit dirty yet still charming. However, not all experiences were positive; one customer ordered a meat lovers pizza but received a vegetarian one instead, leading to further dissatisfaction with the response from staff. Overall, it appears the restaurant has potential with its offerings, but customers have raised valid concerns regarding food hygiene and service consistency.

formattedAddress: 365 Front St W, Toronto, ON M5V 3S8, Canada
editorialSummary: Relaxed chain restaurant for signature & build-your-own pizzas, plus sandwiches & salads.
reviews: Pizza Nova has received mixed reviews from patrons, highlighting both excellent and disappointing experiences. Some customers rave about the party size pepperoni, deluxe, and chicken Florentina pizzas, praising their delicious taste and perfect preparation. Others enjoyed medium and hot wings, which were described as very tasty. However, one reviewer expressed strong dissatisfaction after receiving a vegetarian pizza topped with pepperoni, indicating a serious lack of attention to customer preferences. Another customer noted that their medium pizza with pineapples was delightful and appreciated the fast service at this location. Despite the enjoyment of the food, the online ordering process was criticized for being difficult to navigate. Additionally, there were complaints about the lack of access to the washroom, even after repeated requests. Overall, while the pizza is noted as amazing, improvements in customer service and quality control are necessary.

formattedAddress: 1130 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5H 2M9, Canada
editorialSummary: Casual late-night pizza joint with enormous slices, plus oven-baked pastas, sandwiches & calzones.
reviews: King Slice is a highly rated pizza spot offering oversized slices that are both delicious and well-portioned, making for a great dining experience. Many patrons have enjoyed the Margherita slice, which is enhanced by a flavorful garlic and parsley oil, and described as massive for a reasonable price of around $7.30 to $8.30. Whether visiting for lunch or a late-night snack, diners appreciate the quick service from attentive and friendly staff, which contributes to an enjoyable atmosphere. The Arabiata special slice has also received rave reviews, with customers noting its incredible taste and ideal base texture. Though prices may be considered on the higher side, the quality and size of the pizza justifies the cost. It's advisable to order ahead to avoid long wait times, especially during busy hours. Overall, King Slice is recommended for pizza lovers seeking generous portions and great flavors.

formattedAddress: 796 College St, Toronto, ON M6G 1C6, Canada
editorialSummary: Traditional & gourmet stone-baked pizzas, with options like gluten-free crust & pesto sauce.
reviews: This downtown Toronto pizza shop has garnered a mix of impressions from its patrons. Many guests rave about the delicious cheese pizza, praising its crunchy crust, tasty tomato sauce, and the well-cooked, lightly spicy pepperoni. One reviewer noted the pride and care the staff exhibited, even close to closing time, ensuring the pizza was perfect. However, some customers have expressed disappointment regarding service issues, particularly with the timing of pickup for a "Too Good To Go" surprise bag and concerns about pricing discrepancies at checkout. While some diners appreciate the nice atmosphere and insist on trying pizzas made by an employee named Bhargav, others have reported dissatisfaction with their experiences, including claims of tampered pizzas. Overall, the establishment has potential, but it seems there are inconsistencies in service and reliability that need to be addressed.

formattedAddress: 703 College St, Toronto, ON M6G 1C2, Canada
editorialSummary: Relaxed chain restaurant for signature & build-your-own pizzas, plus sandwiches & salads.
reviews: Pizza Nova has received mixed reviews, particularly for one downtown location that some patrons find to be the best in the area, while others express significant dissatisfaction. Many customers appreciate the well-distributed toppings and well-cooked pizzas, although wait times for service can be lengthy, and staff interactions have been described as lacking warmth and professionalism. While some diners enjoyed their pizza while it was warm, others reported receiving cold slices and poorly cut pieces, leading to disappointment. Specific criticisms have been aimed at the customer service, with one reviewer noting a particularly negative experience with a rude staff member. Several customers highlighted that the quality of the crust and toppings can vary significantly, with some pizzas described as burnt or resembling cardboard. Despite the poor experiences, there are those who feel positively and plan to return, indicating that the location has potential when both food quality and service are on point. Overall, patrons seem to have had varying luck with their meals and the overall dining experience at this Pizza Nova location.

formattedAddress: 471 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4Y 1A1, Canada
reviews: The reviews for Pizza Pizza present a mixed experience, primarily centered around the dinner and late-night meal offerings. While the pizza itself receives praise for its flavor and crispy crust, with specific mention of a delicious three meat Stromboli that was hot and packed with toppings, the overall customer experience leaves much to be desired. Several reviewers highlighted significant issues with service, pointing out rude staff behavior and inadequate hygiene practices, such as employees not wearing gloves and using their shirts as hand towels while handling food. The atmosphere was also criticized, with complaints about loud music making communication difficult while ordering. Despite a positive experience from one reviewer who appreciated a friendly cashier amidst the busy conditions, the recurring themes of impersonal service and poor cleanliness overshadow the quality of the food. Ultimately, while the flavors of the dishes may entice customers, the establishment needs to address its service and hygiene issues to enhance the overall dining experience.

formattedAddress: 228 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1Z6, Canada
reviews: Pizza Pizza provides a generally positive dining experience, particularly for those seeking a quick and satisfying meal. Diners have enjoyed their medium pizzas with a variety of toppings, noting the flavorful crust and prompt service, receiving their orders within 15 minutes, though occasional inconsistencies in crust thickness have been reported. However, some experiences have been less than ideal, especially with delivery issues and customer service; one customer detailed a frustrating encounter where their pizza was not delivered to the specified location due to a lack of cooperation from the delivery staff. For those dining in, suggestions from the friendly staff enhance the experience, and the ambiance is pleasant with scenic views of trams outside. The garlic chicken sandwich and fries received negative feedback, with the fries being criticized for hardness and the sandwich for its poor freshness. On a positive note, patrons recommend trying the creamy garlic base for an extra flavor boost in pizzas. Overall, while the restaurant has some standout offerings, it does have room for improvement in certain areas, particularly in service consistency and delivery reliability.

formattedAddress: 171 E Liberty St Unit 127B, Toronto, ON M6K 3P6, Canada
editorialSummary: Traditional & gourmet stone-baked pizzas, with options like gluten-free crust & pesto sauce.
reviews: Pizzaville offers a mixed dining experience for pizza lovers, with various reviews highlighting both the positives and negatives. Customers have noted the disappointment in their pepperoni slice, describing it as cheese-less and resembling cardboard, while others praised a large three-topping pizza with fresh ingredients like pepperoni, mushrooms, and green peppers, emphasizing its perfectly crispy crust. While some diners were frustrated with long wait times for potato wedges, the overall quality of the pizza seems to stand out. Prices are reasonable, making it a convenient option for a quick meal, especially with offerings like a big slice and soda for under $8. The restaurant is also noted for its pleasant ambiance, contributing to an enjoyable dining experience. On the bright side, complimentary mints are a unique touch that customers appreciate. However, there are stark contrasts in customer satisfaction, with some declaring it the worst meal they've ever had, underscoring the inconsistent quality. Whether for a casual lunch or dinner, Pizzaville certainly sparks varied opinions among patrons.

formattedAddress: 558 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6G 1K1, Canada
reviews: Pizza Pizza at 558 Bloor Street West has received mixed reviews from customers. While some patrons praise the restaurant for its exceptional "Supreme Delight" pizza and welcoming atmosphere, others have expressed frustration over cleanliness issues and poor restroom availability. The pizza is commended for its top-notch ingredients and unparalleled taste, making it a solid choice for both traditional and adventurous pizza lovers. Many have highlighted the reasonable prices and great value, especially with specials available. Service has been described as friendly and attentive, with some customers noting particularly positive experiences during their visits. However, concerns about untidiness and recurring restroom closures have led to disappointing experiences for others. Despite the inconsistencies, most agree that the restaurant ranks highly in terms of flavor and customer service. Overall, it remains a popular spot for pizza lovers, especially those in search of a satisfying dinner option.

formattedAddress: 164 The Esplanade, Toronto, ON M5A 4H2, Canada
editorialSummary: Pasta & pizza, plus burgers & souvlaki, in an unassuming setting with indoor & outdoor seating.
reviews: Bellissimo Pizzeria & Ristorante offers a mix of Italian dishes that range from delicious to average, making it a suitable spot for casual dining. The pizzas, especially the Margherita and calabrese, have received praise for their generous toppings and flavorful sauces, with customers appreciating the option to customize their own pizzas. However, appetizers like garlic bread were deemed standard, while main courses such as ravioli and veal parmigiana were noted as somewhat unimpressive, lacking the distinct flavor expected from Italian cuisine. Dinner guests have enjoyed dishes like spaghetti with tomato sauce, although the ravioli left some wanting more in terms of both portion and taste. Desserts, particularly the tiramisu, were a highlight, featuring a well-balanced flavor profile. The ambiance, while cozy, felt more bar-like than traditional Italian, which surprised some visitors. Service has been described as friendly and attentive, contributing positively to the overall experience. While Bellissimo may not reach culinary excellence, it remains a reliable choice for a decent meal, with some recommending it for a casual outing.

formattedAddress: 9 Charles St W, Toronto, ON M4Y 1R4, Canada
editorialSummary: Relaxed pizzeria serving Detroit-style fare in unfussy surroundings, plus a patio.
reviews: The restaurant offers a variety of deep dish pizzas that receive mixed reviews from patrons. While some customers rave about the freshness, delicious flavors, and cheesy goodness of options like the Detroit Red Top and Oh Canada, others criticize the quality of the food, describing it as tough and unappetizing, likening it to cardboard. The size of the pizzas is also a recurring theme, as they are considered small, typically serving four pieces instead of the previous six, leading to some disappointment during busy lunch hours when the limited seating becomes apparent. Despite the shortcomings in cleanliness and seating capacity, many diners still find the dining experience worthwhile, with a recommendation to enjoy the pizza in smaller groups. The service is generally noted to be pleasant, adding to the overall positive vibe of the establishment. If you're a fan of pizza, especially loaded with pepperoni or a unique white sauce twist, this place might just be your next favorite spot. However, be prepared for a wait of 15-20 minutes if you choose to dine in, as freshness seems to be a priority here.

formattedAddress: 331 Adelaide St W, Toronto, ON M5V 2G5, Canada
displayName: General Assembly Pizza + Sam James Coffee Bar
editorialSummary: Individual pies topped with upscale ingredients plus salads, wine & beer served in a lofty space.
reviews: This casual and cozy restaurant in Toronto offers a unique selection of personal-sized pizzas, such as the Fern Gully and King Shroom, alongside classic salads, gelato, and a variety of wines and cocktails. Open later than most venues in the area, it serves as a great post-show dining option where customers order at the counter and enjoy the ambiance created by an open kitchen. While many patrons rave about their pizzas and recommend making reservations during peak hours, some recent reviews highlight a disappointing experience with frozen pizzas, which were criticized for their poor quality and excessive packaging. Despite mixed reviews on the frozen options, the original artisan pizzas made with a homemade sourdough starter are highly regarded. Diners appreciate the affordable pricing, especially when ordering combo deals of pizza with beer or wine. The venue also encourages patrons to indulge in dessert from their partnership with Death in Venice Gelato, offering a perfect sweet finish to the meal. Whether you're looking for a relaxed dinner, a satisfying late-night slice, or a casual brunch, this spot is adorned with great urban music and a welcoming atmosphere. Overall, this restaurant is considered worth a visit for authentic Italian pizza lovers.

formattedAddress: 37 Blue Jays Way, Toronto, ON M5V 9G9, Canada
regularOpeningHours: ['Monday: Open 24 hours', 'Tuesday: Open 24 hours', 'Wednesday: Open 24 hours', 'Thursday: Open 24 hours', 'Friday: Open 24 hours', 'Saturday: Open 24 hours', 'Sunday: Open 24 hours']
editorialSummary: Petite pizzeria with limited seating, serving gourmet pies, salads, panini & pastas, plus espresso.
reviews: At our recent visit to a restaurant in Toronto, we encountered a mix of experiences. Some diners reported significant delays, waiting over 20 minutes for a margarita pizza and pasta, with complaints about poorly cleaned utensils and rude management. Others praised the friendly waitress who provided helpful tips for local sightseeing, noting that the food was decent but not exceptional. Highlights included the Jambalaya linguine, which was well-received for its variety of ingredients, and a grilled vegetable pizza, appreciated for its flavorful toppings. However, there were criticisms for pizzas being undercooked and overpriced, along with difficulties in obtaining refunds for unsatisfactory meals. Despite some friendly service and decent decor, many felt that there are better dining options in Toronto for similar or lower prices. Overall, the restaurant seems to be a hit or miss, with diners potentially leaving unsatisfied.

formattedAddress: 946 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6H 1L6, Canada
reviews: Ambassador Pizza offers a unique culinary experience with its Windsor-style pizza, renowned for its crispy crust featuring a hint of cornmeal and shredded pepperoni. Customers rave about the standout dishes, including the classic Ambassador Pizza and the inventive TBQ rib pizza, with many deeming it among the best pizza in Toronto. The quality of the ingredients is notable, as they source Galati cheese from Windsor, enhancing authenticity. While the taste received positive feedback, some reviews pointed out concerns regarding the portion sizes and pricing, with customers feeling that the extra charges for additional toppings like pepperoni and cheese were excessive. Despite the pricing issues and some underwhelming experiences with individual slices, the overall flavor left a lasting impression. The ambiance is complemented by a great selection of beers, making it a worthwhile venue for pizza lovers. Overall, Ambassador Pizza is recommended for those seeking a delightful dinner experience, but patrons should be aware of the potential for high costs relative to portion size.

formattedAddress: 340 Front St W, Toronto, ON M5V 3W7, Canada
reviews: The reviews for this pizza restaurant show a pattern of dissatisfaction with customer service and food quality. Multiple customers reported poor experiences, particularly criticizing one staff member's rude behavior and a lack of consistency in offers, as one was denied a deal while others received it. One reviewer ordered an extra-large pizza with pepperoni and bacon but found it poorly cooked and even had raw bacon on it, which led to an exchange for a new pizza that was equally disappointing. Another mentioned their excitement about ordering a couple of extra-large pizzas before a ballgame, but overall the sentiment was overshadowed by negative experiences. Customers expressed frustration over the staff's treatment and the need for improvement in service and food preparation. The outlet has been described as consistently failing to meet expectations, with one guest declaring they would not return. Overall, diners seeking quality pizza and good service may want to reconsider visiting this location.

formattedAddress: 1200 Bay St. #4, Toronto, ON M5R 2A5, Canada
editorialSummary: Compact, modern counter-serve eatery offering build-your-own Neapolitan-style pizzas.
reviews: This restaurant offers a variety of wood-fired pizzas, including the option to create your own, which many customers enjoy for its chewy dough. The Margherita pizza is particularly recommended, highlighting the quality of ingredients used. While some diners found the pizza sizes, such as the Yorkville pizza, to be disappointingly small and overpriced, others appreciated the flavor and quick service. The location is convenient, with easy access to public transportation and local attractions, making it a suitable stop during a stroll. However, the seating situation is lacking, with limited clean tables and small dining space, which may deter some customers. Additionally, some patrons have mentioned the presence of a homeless individual outside, raising concerns about the overall dining experience. Despite these criticisms, the restaurant reportedly runs great promotions, such as a popular Pi Day offer, making it a potential choice for takeout meals. Overall, it's a mixed review with both positive and negative aspects worth considering for a casual pizza outing.

formattedAddress: 170 University Ave, Toronto, ON M5H 3B3, Canada
reviews: Pico is a favorite spot for delicious and reasonably dietary pizzas, with a diverse menu that caters to various tastes. Many guests rave about their favorite pizzas, especially the walnut and goat cheese option and the classic Margherita, which features a light dough and a perfect sauce and cheese combination. While the craft pizza tends to be a bit sour due to excess jalapeños and pineapple, the overall pizza quality is exceptional, and most recommend sticking to the main menu. The service is noted for being friendly and efficient, with pizzas prepared fresh in about 10-15 minutes in a fire oven. Guests also enjoyed sharing a Greek salad with chicken, although opinions on salads seem mixed. Overall, Pico provides a satisfying and cost-effective option for a lunch or dinner date, especially in an area with limited food options on Sundays. Don’t forget to try the cookies for a sweet end to your meal!

formattedAddress: 68 Wellesley St E, Toronto, ON M4Y 1H2, Canada
reviews: Pizza Pizza offers a variety of pizza options, making it a popular choice for those craving a tasty meal. Their pizzas, known for their cheesy goodness and pillowy crust, are available in both vegetarian and non-vegetarian versions, with a medium pizza available for a great deal at $8.99. While the atmosphere can get crowded due to the small space, the staff is generally friendly and eager to assist customers. However, recent experiences have highlighted issues with customer service, particularly regarding an aggressive interaction with a staff member that left a sour impression on a long-time patron. Despite the mixed feelings about service, many still appreciate the reliability of the food, which fits the expectations for a Pizza Pizza. It's worth noting that this location is situated in the Gay Entertainment district, where the food quality is typically standardized but may lack some excitement. Additionally, the area can see some aggressive behavior from homeless individuals during late-night hours. Overall, while the pizza is rated highly, customers are advised to be mindful of the environment and service.

formattedAddress: 2295 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4P 2C6, Canada
reviews: This restaurant has received mixed reviews, particularly highlighting the quality of its pizza. Many diners enjoy the taste and generous portions, especially of the fries, making it worth a return visit despite some negative aspects. Issues were raised about cleanliness, with reports of finding hair in a pizza slice and staff not wearing hairnets, which detracts from the dining experience. Although the food is praised, some customers feel the atmosphere is lacking and that orders take an inordinate amount of time to prepare. Additionally, while some staff members are friendly and attentive, there have been consistent complaints about a specific female worker exhibiting a rude attitude, which has led to an uncomfortable experience for some patrons. However, others have had positive interactions, noting the helpfulness of the staff when ordering takeout. Overall, while the pizza's quality and taste keep many returning, the restaurant faces challenges with cleanliness and staff demeanor that could be addressed to enhance customer satisfaction.

formattedAddress: 1923 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4S 1Z3, Canada
reviews: This local pizzeria offers typical pizza options, with some customers finding the slices acceptable for the price despite their smaller size. The reviews consistently point out that the food—including pizza slices—tastes just fine, with one diner noting that the slices were warmed up perfectly. However, service experiences seem to dominate the feedback, with several patrons expressing dissatisfaction due to rude and unfriendly staff behavior. Customers have reported feeling unwelcome, as evidenced by incidents like being denied access to washrooms unless they order food. The restaurant's closing time of midnight has also led to awkward encounters, with complaints about being unable to enjoy a meal shortly before closing. Overall, while the food meets basic expectations, the unwelcoming atmosphere and poor service have left many diners disappointed and vowing not to return.

formattedAddress: 832 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M6J 1V3, Canada
displayName: The Fourth Man in the Fire Pizzeria
editorialSummary: Casual Italian-American eatery serving up pizzas, calzones & salads, plus beer & wines.
reviews: Fourth Man in the Fire has been praised as one of the best dining experiences in Toronto, especially for its outstanding pizza and delightful desserts. Guests have raved about the mozzarella sticks and the 18-inch vegetarian pizza, noting the fresh ingredients and great flavor. The restaurant’s ambiance, adorned with satirical celebrity pictures, adds to the enjoyable atmosphere, making it a lovely spot for brunch or dinner. Exceptional customer service has been highlighted, particularly from staff members like Sim and Vanessa, who ensure that every detail is taken care of for events or casual visits. Patrons enjoy the welcoming attitude of the staff, who are attentive and friendly. Additionally, the famous donut tower has received rave reviews, with many guests making sure to take some home. Many reviewers express a desire to return, establishing Fourth Man in the Fire as a go-to location for pizza lovers and anyone seeking a warm dining experience. Overall, the combination of exquisite food, a charming setting, and genuine hospitality makes this restaurant a highly recommended choice.

formattedAddress: 744 King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1N3, Canada
regularOpeningHours: ['Monday: Open 24 hours', 'Tuesday: Open 24 hours', 'Wednesday: Open 24 hours', 'Thursday: Open 24 hours', 'Friday: Open 24 hours', 'Saturday: Open 24 hours', 'Sunday: Open 24 hours']
reviews: This restaurant offers a unique late-night dining experience, being open 24 hours and serving delicious pizza. Many customers have praised the quality of the pizza, noting the tasty pepperoni and a well-executed thin crust topped with a flavorful rose sauce and various veggie toppings. The friendly and welcoming staff enhance the overall atmosphere, making visits enjoyable. However, some reviews point out inconsistencies, such as insufficient toppings and issues with the pizza crust being floppy and undercooked. Despite these criticisms, many diners appreciate the cleanliness of the establishment and the quick service. Overall, this place is recommended for its great pizza and friendly vibe, although improvements are needed in consistency and the ordering experience through their app.

formattedAddress: 91 Dundas St E, Toronto, ON M5B 2C8, Canada
editorialSummary: Part of a chain, this vibrant Japanese noodle restaurant specializes in ramen in pork bone broth.
reviews: This ramen restaurant has received rave reviews for its authentic and flavorful dishes, making it a favorite among both locals and visitors. Popular menu items include the Shio Ramen, Kara Miso Ramen, and Combo Ramen, which many patrons found to be surprisingly close to the taste of genuine Japanese ramen. Diners appreciate the option to customize the salt levels in their ramen, making it easier to suit their preferences. Additionally, the Taro ice cream and melon soda float have been highlighted as delicious beverages to complement the meal. While the price-to-portion ratio is reasonable, some noted that the servings are slightly smaller but still satisfying. The restaurant's atmosphere is cozy, albeit a bit cramped, and patrons have noted the friendly and fluent Japanese-speaking staff. Though they do not accept reservations, visiting during off-peak hours can help with seating. Overall, this place stands out for its great quality ramen and a welcoming dining experience perfect for dinner after a long day.

formattedAddress: 396 Church St, Toronto, ON M5B 2A2, Canada
reviews: Kinton Ramen is a standout destination for delicious ramen, offering a range of options perfect for lunch or dinner. Many diners rave about the signature Pork Spicy Garlic ramen, praised for its garlicky broth and perfectly chewy noodles, although some prefer a softer texture. Others have enjoyed the Chicken Spicy Jalapeño ramen, which boasts a flavorful soup base and impressive spice levels that enhance the dining experience. The Beef Mazemen and Pork Miso also receive commendations for their quality and quick service. Additionally, the Pork Gyoza, with its crispy exterior and savory filling, is a must-try. The atmosphere is described as welcoming, with attentive staff like Hayley providing friendly service. Special summer offerings like the intense matcha ice cream have also delighted guests. Overall, Kinton Ramen comes highly recommended for those wanting to enjoy authentic Japanese cuisine in Toronto.

formattedAddress: 1330 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M6K 1L4, Canada
reviews: Kaminari Ramen Bar is a cozy and welcoming restaurant that offers some of the best ramen experiences in the city, ideal for both casual outings and date nights. Diners rave about the unique spicy cucumber appetizer and the standout vegan miso ramen with egg, praised for its exceptional flavor and rich broth. Guests also enjoyed the creamy shio and creamy soy ramens, with the former featuring delicious clams that enhanced the dish's taste. The duck umami, despite past negative reviews, surprised one guest, with a partner rating it a perfect 10/10. The attentive staff, who are considerate of dietary restrictions, contribute to the pleasant atmosphere, making diners feel right at home. On tap, the Asahi draught beer is a popular choice, though availability can be inconsistent. While the decor is simple, the restaurant maintains cleanliness and provides a charming vibe, albeit with access issues due to narrow stairs. Overall, Kaminari Ramen Bar impresses with its delicious food, friendly service, and a diverse menu suitable for meals any time of the day.

formattedAddress: 332 Spadina Ave., Toronto, ON M5T 2G2, Canada
editorialSummary: Renowned for its pork broth, this casual Japanese chain offers a variety of soups & rice dishes.
reviews: Ajisen Ramen in Toronto’s Chinatown is highly praised for its impressive selection of ramen, including the standout filet mignon ramen with spicy miso, which many found irresistibly delicious. The restaurant offers a cozy, albeit small, dining space with fast, friendly service that rivals even Michelin-starred establishments. Diners appreciate the availability of vegan broth options, enhancing its appeal. While the aromatic ramen and flavorsome dishes like spicy beef and sizzling beef steak consistently impress, some patrons noted that the marinated eggs could use improvement. Despite minor cleanliness issues in the washrooms and aging furniture, the atmosphere remains inviting. Visitors often recommend trying various ramen dishes, as the flavor balance impresses, making it a top choice for dinner in the area. Overall, Ajisen Ramen is celebrated for delivering satisfying meals and is a must-visit for ramen enthusiasts.

formattedAddress: 90 Eglinton Ave E Unit 108, Toronto, ON M4P 2Y3, Canada
reviews: This restaurant offers a vibrant dining experience, particularly noted during dinner with friends, highlighted by their tasty veg gyoza served with a tangy sauce. The main attraction is their ramen, featuring options like Spicy Beef, Spicy Chicken, and Spicy Veg; many reviewers prefer the Spicy Beef and Veg for their robust flavors, while the Spicy Chicken is seen as less impactful. The pork donburi also received mixed feedback, praised for its generous portion but critiqued for being overly mayonnaise-heavy despite the well-cooked pork. For dessert, diners enjoyed Green Tea Ice Cream and Mango and Sesame Cheesecake, which added a sweet finish to the meal. The ambiance on weekdays is calm and relaxing, making it a nice spot to unwind. Guests appreciated the unique offerings, including gluten-free potato noodles for those with dietary restrictions. A particularly favorite dish is the Spicy Vegetable ramen, celebrated for its healing properties when feeling under the weather. Overall, the restaurant has garnered positive feedback for its flavors and service, making it a recommended choice for both novice and experienced ramen enthusiasts.

formattedAddress: 424 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5V 2A7, Canada
reviews: This ramen shop has garnered high praise for its exceptional dishes and inviting atmosphere. Visitors recommend trying both the non-spicy ramen and the spicy variety, which features incredibly flavorful minced meat. The standout dish is the Signature Yuzu Scallop Shio Consommé, known for its delicate and well-balanced yuzu flavor, complemented by expertly cooked pork, wontons, and scallops. Diners particularly appreciate the attention to presentation, with beautifully arranged ingredients making each bowl visually stunning. Many highlight the creamy soup and tender noodles, with particular nods to the rich flavor of truffle ramen as well. Cocktails served with crystal clear ice balls showcase the establishment's commitment to detail and quality. Overall, the friendly service adds to an enjoyable dining experience, making this ramen spot a must-visit in downtown Toronto. Both brunch and dinner offerings are noted for their richness and satisfaction, ensuring visitors leave delighted and eager to return.

formattedAddress: 668 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6G 1L2, Canada
editorialSummary: Bar stools line the open kitchen at this modern & simple place offering custom ramen bowls & tapas.
reviews: Kinton Ramen has garnered a mix of reviews for its offerings, making it a popular spot for quick and satisfying meals. Many diners rave about the deliciousness of their dishes, particularly the spicy garlic vegetarian dish, which is recommended with thick noodles for an amazing texture. The kimchi, however, has received criticism for being overly fermented. For lunch, the restaurant offers affordable specials and fresh ingredients, with patrons appreciating the delightful flavor and impressive value. Diners have tried various ramen options, including the Gekikara chili ramen, Miso ramen, and Chicken ramen, with mixed ratings between 6/10 and 7/10, while noting the presence of pork, bamboo, and seasoned eggs. Although the seating can be slightly uncomfortable, the service and atmosphere are praised. A definite highlight is the crispy dumplings, which enhance the ramen experience. This restaurant is seen as a reliable choice, especially during cold winter days.

formattedAddress: 402 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5V 2A6, Canada
reviews: At Kinton Ramen, diners can expect an exceptional experience highlighted by top-notch service, particularly from staff member Ryan, who is noted for his fantastic customer care. The restaurant specializes in ramen, featuring a flavorful broth and perfectly cooked noodles that many patrons rave about. One standout dish is the kimchi, praised for its quality, while the eggs are particularly beloved for their enhanced flavor after being dipped in the broth. Many recommend trying the takoyaki, described as soft with an incredible texture and flavor that leaves a lasting impression. While some guests feel the garlic in the ramen could be a bit overwhelming, the overall satisfaction with the meal remains high. The atmosphere is cozy and inviting, making it an ideal spot for a quick and satisfying lunch or dinner. With impressive customer service and a welcoming environment, Kinton Ramen comes highly recommended for anyone seeking delicious ramen.

formattedAddress: 153 Liberty St, Toronto, ON M6K 3G3, Canada
reviews: Kinton Ramen offers a mixed dining experience with a variety of ramen options and sides. Customers frequently mention dishes such as the Chicken Miso Ramen, Veg Spicy Garlic Ramen, and Beef Shoyu, noting that while some ramen, like the original, can be a bit plain, others are flavorful and well-received, particularly the spicy garlic varieties. The portion sizes have been criticized as being somewhat lacking, especially for the price, with complaints regarding inconsistent serving sizes reflected in takeout orders. However, the delicious cheesecakes, including both mango and matcha, stood out as a highlight for many diners. Service is often described as friendly and accommodating, adding to a generally positive atmosphere within the restaurant. The Meal for Two option, featuring signature ramen and gyozas, is recommended for couples. Overall, while some dishes might fall short of expectations, the restaurant's pleasant environment and tasty offerings make it worth a visit for ramen lovers seeking a casual dining spot.

formattedAddress: 249 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1Z4, Canada
editorialSummary: Pared-sown eatery dishing up bowls of traditional Japanese ramen, plus gyoza & fried chicken wings.
reviews: This popular ramen restaurant is known for its excellent service and authentic flavors, making it a favorite among locals, especially during lunch or dinner when wait times can be expected. Diners rave about the thick and flavorful tonkotsu broth, which is recommended as a starting point, along with the spicy God fire ramen that has varying spice levels for those seeking heat. Many suggest adding side dishes like gyoza, karaage, or takoyaki for a more filling meal. Although the ramen is delicious, some customers note that the portion sizes may be on the smaller side, and prices increase with add-ons. The ambiance is cozy, with seating near the bar, an environment well-suited for small groups or solo dining. It's advisable to utilize the loyalty program for regular patrons, and there’s a unique birthday promotion for those who bring proof of their birth date. Overall, this restaurant combines rich flavors, friendly service, and a lively atmosphere, making it a go-to destination for ramen lovers in the area.

formattedAddress: 2057 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4S 2A2, Canada
reviews: Santouka is a highly recommended spot for ramen enthusiasts, offering a cozy atmosphere and attentive service. The menu features a variety of dishes, most notably their delicious ramen options like the Toroniku Kara-Miso Ramen, Miso Cha-Shu Ramen, and Spicy Tsukemen, catering well to those craving a satisfying dinner. Diners have praised the rich and flavorful broth, particularly noting the tenderness of the pork cheek and the seasoning of the pork belly. However, opinions vary about the texture of the noodles, with some finding them lacking a desirable chewiness. The restaurant also offers extras like mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and takoyaki to enhance the meal experience, though opinions on the additional bamboo shoots were less favorable. For those seeking other flavors, the Spicy Veggie Ramen has been highlighted as a standout, boasting a unique and hearty taste. Accessibility is a plus, with provisions for guests with disabilities and a kid-friendly environment. Overall, Santouka is acknowledged for maintaining quality standards, making it a reliable choice for a pleasant dining experience focused on authentic and flavorful ramen.

formattedAddress: 257 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1Z4, Canada
reviews: This restaurant garners mixed reviews, particularly for its ramen offerings, which are noted for their rich flavors and customizable options. Many patrons praise the savory chicken broth, claiming it's one of the best they've tasted, complemented by perfectly cooked noodles and a selection of add-ons like garlic and sesame. However, some diners found the broth to be bland, especially in the white soup and clear soup varieties, expressing disappointment with the lack of richness and creaminess. The spicy soup ramen, dubbed "God Fire," received a positive nod for its flavor, though some felt the portion size was small. The fried chicken stands out as a highlight, boasting a delicious lemon pepper flavor without the need for dipping sauce. While service is generally described as excellent, the atmosphere is noted to be cramped, discouraging large groups. Despite varied experiences with the food, many customers express a desire to return, intrigued by the possibility of finding a new favorite dish. Overall, this ramen spot remains a popular choice among locals, offering a mix of delectable and lackluster options.

formattedAddress: 110 Harbour St Unit 108A, Toronto, ON M5J 2L9, Canada
reviews: Kinton Ramen offers a mix of authentic Japanese cuisine that has garnered mixed reviews. Diners have enjoyed dishes such as the Pork Miso and Chicken Miso ramen, with the Pork Miso being particularly favored for its flavorful broth. The restaurant also provides vegetarian options and enticing sides like Pork and Veg Dumplings, which were praised when customers used their prestos for a discount. However, there were some disappointing experiences as well, including complaints about the quality of meat, with one review citing the use of processed deli meat in place of pork shoulder. Patrons have sampled other dishes, like the spicy garlic chicken and original karage, which received positive feedback for their flavors. Some customers appreciated the “meal for two” deal for its value, but others expressed concern over inconsistent meat quality. Overall, the atmosphere and service were frequently noted as pleasant, with staff being accommodating and attentive to diners' needs. Despite some quality issues, many are still eager to return for the unique Japanese flavors offered.

formattedAddress: 596 College St, Toronto, ON M6G 1B4, Canada
editorialSummary: Ramen bowls & informal Japanese fare served in a down-to-earth corner eatery with sidewalk tables.
reviews: Tondou Ramen is an unforgettable dining destination that offers a delightful culinary experience characterized by its authentic atmosphere and exceptional service. The menu features standout dishes such as the Okinawan Soba and Tonkotsu Ramen, both of which have received rave reviews for their rich flavors. Diners have particularly praised the Chicken Karaage for its moist texture and the Garlic Oil Ramen, although some found it slightly over-salted. The cozy, clean environment, accentuated by charming decorations like Shiisaa, adds to the overall enjoyment. Guests can also enjoy a pleasant dining experience on the shaded patio, ideal for summer visits. The cold ramen options are perfect for hot days, and the alcohol-free mojito has been described as refreshingly delicious. Overall, Tondou Ramen is noted for its amazing Chashu Pork, which is said to melt in your mouth, making it a must-visit for ramen enthusiasts in Toronto.

formattedAddress: 411 Church St Unit 1, Toronto, ON M4Y 2C2, Canada
reviews: Afuri is a popular ramen restaurant known for its authentic Japanese fare and friendly staff, offering a delightful dining experience. The menu features a range of dishes, with a focus on their signature ramen, which is infused with yuzu for a refreshing twist. Guests rave about the fresh flavors and quality of the food, highlighting the deliciousness of the ramen combos that include a bowl of ramen, a small plate, and a drink. While some diners enjoyed the lightness of the yuzu-infused broth, others found it overpowering, particularly in the Yuzu Shio option. The restaurant also serves tasty appetizers like bao and dumplings, further enhancing the meal experience. The ambiance is clean, spacious, and well-decorated, contributing to a relaxed atmosphere. Despite some minor service hiccups, such as cleaning during meal times, overall experiences indicate a strong connection to authentic Japanese cuisine and a welcoming environment. Many patrons express their eagerness to return, making it a recommended spot for ramen enthusiasts.

formattedAddress: 399 Church St, Toronto, ON M5B 2A1, Canada
editorialSummary: Renowned for its pork broth, this casual Japanese chain offers a variety of soups & rice dishes.
reviews: Ajisen Ramen in Toronto has garnered rave reviews for its exceptional offerings, particularly for dinner. Diners have praised the Spicy Chicken Ramen and Original Ramen with Sizzler Beef, noting the perfect texture of the ramen noodles and the extraordinary broth that combines depth of flavor and smokiness. The restaurant is appreciated for its fresh toppings, juicy meats, and generous portion sizes, ensuring guests leave satisfied. The service is described as friendly and efficient, with quick turnaround times from seating to serving. Many guests have highlighted the cozy atmosphere and clean environment, making it a comfortable dining experience. The highlights also include sharing appetizers like seaweed salad and katsu curry, while not sampling the ramen, which remains a highly anticipated return visit option. Overall, Ajisen Ramen stands out as a must-try establishment for both ramen enthusiasts and those seeking delightful Japanese cuisine.

formattedAddress: 1 Richmond St W, Toronto, ON M5H 3W4, Canada
reviews: Kinton Ramen Express offers a unique dining experience with a focus on delicious, budget-friendly meals, particularly known for their ramen. Located downtown, it serves as a convenient spot for lunch and features self-service kiosks for quick ordering. Customers have praised the cheerful and efficient staff, who provide helpful recommendations and ensure a pleasant atmosphere. Popular dishes include the Spicy Beef Mazemen, which is noted for its bold flavors and perfectly cooked noodles, and the Pork Miso Ramen, which closely resembles offerings from regular Kinton locations. While customization options are available, such as adding protein for an extra charge, some diners express a desire for preset options to simplify their choices. Vegetarian options are also available, making it a great introduction to ramen for first-timers. However, some patrons have raised concerns about the use of plastic and additional costs for toppings like seaweed, feeling it detracts from the dining experience. Overall, Kinton Ramen Express is a cozy, affordable eatery ideal for a warm bowl of ramen, especially during cooler weather.

formattedAddress: 51 Baldwin St, Toronto, ON M5T 1L1, Canada
editorialSummary: Diners slurp housemade noodles, with a variety of Japanese broths & toppings, at shared counters.
reviews: This restaurant offers a delightful dining experience with a focus on ramen, praised for its delicious broths that are comforting and full of umami. Highlights include the Vegan Shoyu Ramen and Chicken Miso Ramen, both receiving high ratings for freshness and flavor. Diners also enjoyed the Burnt Shoyu Ramen and a side of kimchi, all described as 5/5. However, the service received mixed reviews; while some staff were friendly, others were noted for their lack of warmth, which detracted from the overall experience. The cozy interior blends modern and traditional design elements, making it a nice spot for brunch or dinner. There were some concerns about the timing of service, particularly during quieter hours, and there were specific issues with the temperature of the food, such as lukewarm broth and a cold egg. Nevertheless, patrons remain optimistic about the restaurant's potential for improvement. Overall, it's a place worth revisiting, especially for ramen enthusiasts in Toronto.

formattedAddress: 421 College St, Toronto, ON M5T 1T1, Canada
editorialSummary: Popular destination specializing in Japanese ramen noodle soup, with vegetarian options available.
reviews: Ramen Isshin offers a warm and inviting dining experience, with friendly and attentive service that leaves guests eagerly returning. Known for its delicious ramen, the restaurant doesn't disappoint; a popular choice among visitors is the Garlic Shoyu ramen, praised for its rich and flavorful broth. Guests also rave about the takoyaki and gyoza, perfect for starting the meal on a high note. However, some customers found certain dishes like the Chicken Karaage to be underwhelming, lacking the desired crispiness. While many enjoyed the overall taste of their ramen, there were a few critiques about excessive bean sprouts overpowering the flavor and toppings being somewhat sparse in some options. The ambiance can be quite lively and loud, making for an energetic atmosphere, though it may not be ideal for those seeking a quiet meal. Overall, Ramen Isshin is highly recommended for diners looking for authentic Japanese fare, particularly for a satisfying dinner with friends or family.

formattedAddress: 24 Wellesley St. West Rear, Toronto, ON M4Y 2X6, Canada
editorialSummary: Classically Japanese ramen is served in this casual restaurant with a wood ceiling.
reviews: The restaurant offers a delightful culinary experience, highlighted by its exceptional ramen dishes, including the Hakata Tonkotsu Ramen and a unique seafood pork bone broth ramen. Diners are particularly impressed by the high-quality ingredients and flavorful tonkotsu broth, which is rich without being overly salty. While the service is friendly, some guests have noted that it can be a bit slow during busy lunch hours, leading to awkward moments when servers attempt to clear dishes before diners have finished. The Takoyaki is frequently mentioned as one of the best they've ever tasted, adding to the overall appeal of the menu. One patron appreciated the extra chashu promotion on their tsukemen, making for a refreshing addition. However, some reviews indicated that certain ramen, like the spicy variant, leaned towards excessive saltiness. The atmosphere of the restaurant contributes to its authentic vibe, making it a pleasant spot for brunch or lunch. Overall, while the experiences vary, many customers express a desire to return for another meal.

formattedAddress: 609 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5V 2B7, Canada
reviews: Ramen Isshin in Toronto has quickly garnered a reputation as one of the best ramen restaurants in the city, offering an authentic dining experience that consistently delights visitors. Diners rave about the rich and flavorful broths, with standout dishes including the spicy red miso ramen, miso ramen, black garlic shoyu ramen, and white sesame shio. The staff is known for their warm and welcoming service, providing helpful recommendations to enhance the meal experience. Guests appreciate the ability to customize the heat level of dishes like the Red Dragon and Spicy Miso, perfect for warming up on a cold day. The restaurant also boasts beautifully presented bowls, making for a delightful visual and culinary experience. Many diners have expressed their intent to return, citing the perfectly cooked noodles and the depth of flavor found in the cha shiu and various broths. Additionally, the hot plum ginger wine has received praise as a unique and enjoyable beverage option. Overall, Ramen Isshin is highly recommended for anyone seeking an exceptional ramen dining experience in Toronto.

formattedAddress: 261 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1Z4, Canada
reviews: This Japanese ramen restaurant, rated 4.2 stars, offers a delightful dining experience with a variety of dishes perfect for lunch or dinner. Diners especially enjoyed the pork ramen with egg and the tomato chicken ramen, both praised for their delicious flavors, though some noted shortcomings in spice levels and broth depth. The octopus meatball appetizer received positive remarks, while the gyoza featured a crispy crust but could benefit from a better dipping sauce. The atmosphere, however, received mixed reviews due to issues with temperature control, leaving some patrons feeling uncomfortably cold. Service was highlighted as excellent, with attentive staff checking in regularly. While some customers experienced inconsistency in their meals during different visits, the overall satisfaction remained high, particularly for those dining in rather than opting for takeout. The restaurant's broth, particularly the Tonkotsu, was noted for being reminiscent of authentic Japanese flavors, making it a recommended spot for comfort meals. However, feedback suggests addressing issues like broth consistency and ambiance to enhance the dining experience further.

formattedAddress: 41 Elm St, Toronto, ON M5G 1H1, Canada
editorialSummary: Famed pork bone ramen soup with house-made noodles & toppings in a warm, narrow space.
reviews: This cozy and charming ramen shop offers a unique dining experience with an emphasis on quality ingredients and flavorful dishes. For dinner, guests can enjoy a variety of ramen options, including the popular clam soup ramen and vegetarian ramen, both praised for their distinct flavors. The spicy ramen broth received high marks for its authenticity, while the tonkatsu broth, enhanced with chili oil, left a lasting impression on diners. Accompanying the ramen, fried chicken nuggets (Karaage) and fantastic dumplings are also recommended, with the latter providing a traditional touch. The ambiance, complemented by J-pop music, creates an inviting atmosphere, although some diners noted that the tables could be a bit tidier. Prices are on the higher side, with some meals exceeding $80 for two, yet many agree that the unique menu and attentive service make it worthwhile. Overall, this restaurant is a must-visit for ramen lovers seeking a satisfying and hearty meal.

formattedAddress: 412 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5V 2A7, Canada
editorialSummary: Contemporary space offering Japanese noodle soups & vegetarian options, plus happy-hour specials.
reviews: Midori Ramen offers a delightful dining experience for both newcomers and regulars, with a variety of delicious dishes to choose from. Many patrons rave about the creamy broths, particularly enjoying options like the Tori Paitan Shoyu, Duck Shoyu, and the Red Spicy Vegetarian ramen. Diners have highlighted the flavorful chicken karaage and chicken gyoza as standout appetizers, particularly appreciating the gyoza's tasty filling. While the noodles were praised for their perfect texture, some guests noted a desire for larger portions and more broth. The restaurant's clean and welcoming atmosphere, complemented by friendly service, enhances the overall experience, although peak dinner hours may lead to slightly longer wait times for initial orders. The vegetarian options are intriguing, with one guest mentioning the exceptional Black Garlic Vegetarian ramen. Overall, Midori Ramen is quickly becoming a favorite spot for ramen lovers, especially as the colder weather sets in, encouraging hearty and satisfying meals.

formattedAddress: 46 St Clair Ave E #101, Toronto, ON M4T 1M9, Canada
reviews: Megumi Mazesoba offers a delightful dining experience with a standout menu featuring authentic ramen and other Japanese dishes. Guests rave about the unagi mazesoba, which is enhanced by a runny egg that adds a special touch, and praise the variety of flavors in the mazemen, highlighting its bold taste and diverse toppings. The atmosphere is cozy and family-friendly, creating a welcoming environment bolstered by fast and friendly service. Many reviews commend the culinary offerings, noting that even vegetarians can find satisfying options, such as a flavorful vegetable broth and a crispy vegetable croquette from the appetizer menu. However, not all feedback is positive, with some patrons expressing disappointment over the quality of certain dishes, including the basic noodles and unappealing tempura. Despite a few criticisms, the overall sentiment is that the restaurant is a charming spot to enjoy lunch or dinner, making it likely that diners will return for more delicious meals in the future. Those looking for a delightful brunch or meal in a fun setting will find Megumi Mazesoba a tempting choice.

formattedAddress: 372 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M5S 1X7, Canada
editorialSummary: Buzzing ramen joint with housemade noodles & sauces, plus broth that simmers for 24 hours.
reviews: Kenzo Ramen offers a diverse menu that brings a satisfying taste of Japanese cuisine, especially noted for its ramen dishes. Diners have enjoyed the Tonkotsu King and the King Shoyu ramen, with flavors described as excellent, though some customers felt the noodles were overwhelming and the temperature lukewarm. In addition to ramen, patrons have indulged in Donburi Tonkatsu, gyoza, and takoyaki, all of which were well-received for their flavor and generous portions. However, some experiences were marred by issues such as overly salty dishes and service lapses, including forgotten orders and unsatisfactory beverage preparations like diluted milk tea. The restaurant maintains a cozy atmosphere, with friendly and accommodating staff noted for their attentiveness to allergies. While most guests had positive experiences, some expressed the need for improvements, particularly regarding portion balance and service efficiency. Overall, Kenzo Ramen is a great option for those craving a hearty Japanese meal, making it a worthwhile dining destination for lunch or dinner.

formattedAddress: 179 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M5G 1Z8, Canada
editorialSummary: Easygoing restaurant serving a menu of modern Japanese noodle soup dishes & sides.
reviews: This restaurant in the heart of Toronto specializes in authentic Ramen, offering an impressive dining experience with excellent service and warm hospitality. Guests are welcomed by friendly staff, like Yurika, who are eager to explain menu options, including a variety of noodles and broths. The standout dishes include the tonkotsu black ramen, vegetarian ramen with egg, and spicy pork ramen, all praised for their rich and flavorful broths, chewy noodles, and tender meat. While the portion sizes are generous, some diners noted that the dishes can be quite fatty, leading to a feeling of fullness post-meal. The atmosphere is lively, making it a popular spot for lunch, although it may lack a cozy vibe for some. Overall, the restaurant's dedication to excellent service and delicious food makes it a highly recommended choice for those looking to indulge in a satisfying bowl of ramen without reservations. Many guests expressed a desire to return and try more of the menu offerings on an empty stomach.

formattedAddress: 30 Adelaide St E, Toronto, ON M5C 3G9, Canada
editorialSummary: Easygoing restaurant serving a menu of modern Japanese noodle soup dishes & sides.
reviews: This restaurant on Adelaide Street in Toronto has garnered mixed reviews, particularly for its Tonkotsu ramen. Many diners have praised the Tonkotsu Black, highlighting its rich flavor and excellent service that made their dining experience enjoyable. The atmosphere is described as warm and welcoming, with staff providing efficient service even during busy times. However, some patrons expressed disappointment due to the absence of vegetarian or vegan options, which could limit choices for those with dietary restrictions. In contrast, one reviewer had a starkly negative experience, finding the miso and shoyu ramens unsatisfactory due to what they identified as spoiled meat, mentioning that the chashu pork was notably dry and unpleasant. Despite this, they did commend the zangi, or hyper-seasoned fried chicken, which they felt was exceptional. While many reviews celebrated the restaurant for its ramen and welcoming environment, the inconsistency in food quality has left some diners feeling uncertain about their experience. Overall, the restaurant seems to excel in providing a delightful atmosphere for ramen lovers, though care around ingredient quality is needed.

formattedAddress: 650 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4Y 2A6, Canada
editorialSummary: Easygoing restaurant serving a menu of modern Japanese noodle soup dishes & sides.
reviews: This restaurant is highly praised as one of the best ramen spots in Toronto, with the "Tonkotsu Black" ramen being a standout dish beloved by many patrons. Guests have noted the warm, savory pork bone broth and soft, tender slices of pork, which create a fulfilling dining experience that surpasses typical Toronto Japanese fare. The "Tonkatsu Ramen" is also recommended for those seeking the original taste of this classic dish. The menu includes options like Zangi chicken, which pairs well with the ramen, and diners appreciate the generous portion sizes. Service is described as courteous and attentive, though some have requested better care with dish presentation, as one bowl was chipped. The restaurant is particularly suitable for satisfying cravings during lunch or a cozy dinner date, especially with their combo options that allow for both ramen and a small rice bowl. Overall, the reasonable prices and abundance of space for comfortable dining make this place a go-to for delicious and budget-friendly meals.

formattedAddress: Chef’s Hall, 111 Richmond St W, Toronto, ON M5H 2G4, Canada
reviews: The restaurant is known for its ramen, with mixed reviews from customers. Some diners rave about the Cold Tantan Ramen, claiming it to be the most delicious they've ever had and expressing eagerness to return for more. Others appreciated the unique addition of raw onion in the miso ramen, highlighting the friendly staff and quick service. However, not all feedback is positive; some patrons found the ramen to be overpriced and disappointing, with one customer comparing it unfavorably to instant ramen. The black garlic featured in the dishes received praise for its balanced flavor. Despite the discontent expressed by some regarding the garlic miso soup, others still enjoyed their overall experience.

formattedAddress: 65 Front St W, Toronto, ON M5J 1E6, Canada
editorialSummary: Easygoing restaurant serving a menu of modern Japanese noodle soup dishes & sides.
reviews: Sansotei Ramen, located in the Union Station food court, offers a comforting and flavorful dining experience, particularly for those in need of a quick lunch. The ramen options, especially the Tonkotsu Black ramen and the black miso, stand out for their rich flavors and perfectly cooked noodles. While the restaurant is primarily focused on meat-based broth dishes, it does provide one vegetarian option: the dry spicy noodle. Many reviewers appreciate the quality and taste of the meals, often highlighting the effectiveness of their takeout containers. For an added touch, pairing the ramen with crispy guyoza enhances the overall experience. Although some diners express a desire for more vegetarian selections, the quick service and friendly atmosphere make it an appealing choice for brunch or lunch on the go. Overall, Sansotei Ramen emerges as a strong contender for satisfying ramen within a bustling food court environment.

formattedAddress: 50 Brant St, Toronto, ON M5V 3G9, Canada
reviews: At Musoshin Ramen, diners can indulge in the Special Musoshin Ramen (Ajitama), which features a delightful mix of 4 pieces of chashu, beef tenderloin, fried chicken karage, and seaweed, all for $27.50. Reviewers praised the intense umami flavor of the ramen, highlighting its perfectly chewy and springy noodles. The accompanying pork Tonkatsu was noted for being juicy and flavorful, making for a satisfying side. While the food court setting might lack traditional service, patrons appreciated the kid-friendly environment. The rich tonkotsu broth and torched meats added complexity to the flavor profile, enticing many to come back for more. However, some critics found the pricing steep for a food-court experience, mentioning that the portions felt small and the use of disposable utensils detracted from the overall ambiance. Overall, the experience seems to be a mixed bag, with high marks for flavor but dissatisfaction regarding the portion sizes and pricing.

formattedAddress: 220 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M5B 2H1, Canada
editorialSummary: Easygoing restaurant serving a menu of modern Japanese noodle soup dishes & sides.
reviews: This restaurant, located in the Urban Eatery food court of the Eaton Centre, offers a range of delicious ramen options, making it a popular choice for shoppers seeking a quick meal. Patrons rave about the Spicy Tan Tan ramen, noting its rich broth and perfectly cooked noodles, while others enjoyed the shoyu ramen, although some found the broth a bit strong. The Tonkatsu Ramen is also highlighted for its excellent quality and value, despite being priced at $17 plus tax. Diners appreciate the generous portion sizes, making it a satisfying option for lunch or dinner. The atmosphere can be quite crowded, making it a challenge to find a seat during busy hours, especially for those carrying trays of soup. A complimentary ramune drink promo is a delightful touch that enhances the dining experience. Overall, the restaurant maintains consistent quality across its various locations, with standout features like tender chashu and impeccably cooked eggs.

formattedAddress: 351 King St E #40, Toronto, ON M5A 2W4, Canada
reviews: This new restaurant has garnered positive feedback for its inviting atmosphere and friendly staff, particularly highlighting the excellence of its Beef Garlic Ramen. Diners have praised the flavorful broth, perfectly cooked noodles, and well-seasoned eggs, making it a standout dish for those who enjoy spicy flavors. Service has been noted as attentive, with particular mention of William, who made dining experiences even more enjoyable. Although some reviews indicate that while the food is good, it may not be the best ramen available, most guests agree it offers solid quality at affordable prices. The restaurant's decor adds to the overall positive dining experience, making it a welcomed addition to the neighborhood. Many patrons express their intention to return for both the food and service, with various reviewers appreciating the manager, Adam, for his kindness. Overall, this spot is ideal for anyone looking to enjoy a satisfying meal, especially for dinner or casual outings.

formattedAddress: 671 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M6J 1E6, Canada
reviews: Wonton Hut is an ideal destination for delicious soups, especially on a rainy day. Guests rave about the amazing wonton soup and wonton noodle soup, which feature large, flavorful wontons stuffed with shrimp and pork, complemented by chili oil. The curry fish balls and calamari appetizers have also received high praise, marking them as must-try dishes. The Crab and Tomato soup is celebrated for its fresh flavors, combining lemongrass with a hearty tomato broth, along with fish cake, crab, and tofu. For those looking for a comforting option, the Latska ramen is highly recommended as well. While some diners have critiqued the pho for its lack of aroma and bland broth, the quality of the meatballs and meats is appreciated. The service is noted to be exceptional, with staff taking the time to explain menu items. Overall, Wonton Hut promises a delightful dining experience with a range of delectable soups perfect for a cozy meal.

formattedAddress: Concourse Level, First Canadian Place, Toronto, ON M5X 1A9, Canada
reviews: This Japanese eatery, located in the PATH, is popular for quick lunch and takeout options, often featuring a lineup during peak hours. They offer a variety of dishes including sushi, rice bowls, and udon noodles, with an emphasis on freshness and flavor delivered at reasonable prices. While many reviewers rave about the quality of their sushi, particularly the salmon avocado rolls and dragon rolls, some have had mixed experiences, such as with the Torch Salmon Lovers Set which was unexpectedly fishy. The Torch Combo, priced at $18 and consisting of 12 pieces along with miso soup, has also received mixed feedback regarding the freshness of the fish on recent visits. Although one reviewer described their ramen as the worst they've had, citing poor noodle texture and flavor, others appreciated the well-prepared sushi that is consistently good, even if not the best in town. For those seeking a quick meal, this place is praised for its grab-and-go convenience and high-quality offerings, making it a solid choice for office workers in the area.

formattedAddress: 786 Broadview Ave, Toronto, ON M4K 2P7, Canada
editorialSummary: Relaxed Japanese eatery with bright, simple decor specializing in noodle soups in a signature broth.
reviews: Ryu's Noodle Bar on Broadview is a highly recommended spot for a dinner of delicious ramen. The menu offers a variety of options, including the Vegetarian Shoyu and the spicy Tan Tan Men, both praised for their flavorful broths and generous portions. Diners enjoyed the balance of spices and textures, particularly noting the creamy and rich chicken-broth ramen, which is considered one of the best in Toronto. The "Make Your Own Ramen" option was also a hit, allowing guests to customize dishes with noodles, mushrooms, and tofu. Service at the restaurant was generally praised for being friendly and quick, though there were some minor delays in water and bill requests. The atmosphere can get lively, especially on the patio, so guests should be prepared for potential wait times. Overall, the combination of excellent food, unique broth flavors, and attentive staff makes Ryu's Noodle Bar a great choice for ramen lovers. However, some diners noted minor distractions, such as strong cleaning smells during their visits.

formattedAddress: Sidney Smith Hall 100 St. George St lower level, Toronto, ON M5S 3G3, Canada
reviews: The restaurant received quite unfavorable reviews, especially regarding its ramen dishes, which have been described as the worst ever tasted. One reviewer noted that the ramen lacked soup altogether, making it an unusual experience. Additionally, another diner found the ramen to be excessively spicy and devoid of flavor, further diminishing the overall enjoyment of the meal. Another dish, the "Shanghai noodle with impossible dumpling," was criticized for its undercooked noodles and excessive saltiness, leaving little room for positive feedback. Overall, the lack of quality in both the ramen and other offerings has led to disappointment among customers, suggesting that the restaurant may need to reevaluate its recipes and cooking techniques to improve the dining experience.

formattedAddress: 547 Danforth Ave, Toronto, ON M4K 1P7, Canada
reviews: This restaurant is celebrated for its exceptional ramen offerings, particularly the "Ajitama Spicy Ramen," which features a rich, flavorful broth, tender pork, and cha shu.
