The ambiance is described as pleasant, making it suitable for special occasions such as anniversaries. Overall, while the experience is deemed pricey, many diners feel the combination of atmosphere, service, and certain standout dishes justifies the cost, though a few found their meals disappointing compared to the high prices. Many recommend this steakhouse for those looking to indulge in a premium dining experience, although some caution about potential variability in food quality.

formattedAddress: 605 Rogers Rd #1, York, ON M6M 1B9, Canada
editorialSummary: Specializing in BBQ, this lively eatery with patio serves a wide menu of classic Portuguese fare.
reviews: Martin's restaurant offers a delightful dining experience with its authentic Portuguese cuisine and ample parking. Guests rave about the octopus, which is described as soft and well-seasoned, accompanied by a side of rice that doesn’t come standard with the dish. The atmosphere is welcoming, especially on sunny days when patrons can enjoy the patio. While the bread was not fresh during one visit, the overall impressions highlight large portion sizes and fair pricing. The friendly and attentive service is consistently praised, with specific mention of a waiter named Paulo who delivered exceptional service during a birthday celebration. Many guests have noted the restaurant as a lovely spot for special occasions, like Father's Day, and appreciate the fresh and delicious food served. Overall, Martin's is recommended for those seeking a taste of authentic Portuguese flavors in Toronto.

formattedAddress: 10 Dundas St E 500, 5th Floor, Toronto, ON M5B 2G9, Canada
editorialSummary: Brightly lit, spacious place for Japanese & Thai cuisine, with a patio & touch-screen food ordering.
reviews: Spring Sushi Yonge and Dundas has consistently earned rave reviews as a top sushi destination in Toronto. Diners frequently rave about the incredible freshness of the fish, with highlights including the melt-in-your-mouth salmon sashimi and the perfectly crispy veggie tempura. The all-you-can-eat option is highly popular, especially during dinner, offering a vast array of choices that cater to sushi lovers, including flavorful rolls like the spicy salmon and dynamite roll, as well as the intriguing torched roll. Guests recommend starting with sashimis and tatakis to maximize their experience. Service is notably attentive, with staff like Eddy and Julian being praised for their friendly demeanor and helpful recommendations. The restaurant also takes care to accommodate dietary needs, such as offering gluten-free soy sauce. Whether indulging in a la carte selections or the all-you-can-eat extravaganza, Spring Sushi delivers a memorable dining experience that keeps patrons returning for more. Overall, it’s a sushi lover's paradise where both quality and service shine.

formattedAddress: 525 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M5S 1Y4, Canada
editorialSummary: Popular neighborhood spot serving a wide variety of sushi rolls & other Japanese eats.
reviews: This restaurant has garnered positive reviews for its delicious and well-priced sushi, making it a favorite for many diners over the years. Guests have praised dishes like the Sushi Platinum Combo, which includes unique items like the Black Dragon Roll and is served with miso soup and a salad. The sushi is noted for its freshness, with many recommending the sashimi and the Ginger Wasabi Roll as standout choices. The Makimono set, featuring spicy salmon and tuna rolls, has also been highlighted as a top pick. Additionally, the establishment offers complimentary green tea or mango ice cream at the end of the meal, adding to the overall value. While some reviewers mentioned that prices have increased, they still find the quality and quantity satisfying, often leaving with leftovers like California rolls. The warm and crunchy salmon pizza roll has been a standout dish, alongside the extensive sashimi options. Overall, the friendly staff and the good dining experience keep patrons coming back, despite minor concerns about the decor and one instance of subpar service.

formattedAddress: 451 Church St, Toronto, ON M4Y 2C5, Canada
editorialSummary: Snug Japanese eatery featuring rolls made with haiga (half-milled) rice, hot dishes & bento boxes.
reviews: Kawa on Church Street is a must-visit sushi restaurant known for its friendly staff and efficient service, making it a favored spot for both dining in and takeout. Diners rave about the fresh and tasty offerings, including the Salmon Bento, Sushi and Sashimi combo, and the Shrimp Tempura. The Black Dragon and Spicy Tuna rolls are also highlighted as standout choices, with many patrons praising the Crazy Tuna roll as a top recommendation. Guests appreciate the warm atmosphere created by the owner, who ensures everyone feels taken care of, adding a personal touch to the dining experience. The edamame is a particular favorite, as it is consistently ordered by returning customers. Overall, Kawa delivers great food and a delightful meal experience at reasonable prices, making it an excellent option for sushi lovers in the area. Whether for brunch, lunch, or dinner, this place promises satisfaction and encourages support for local businesses.

formattedAddress: 4 Collier St, Toronto, ON M4W 2G9, Canada
editorialSummary: Intimate eatery offering sushi, sashimi & cooked Japanese specialties amid stylish, modern decor.
reviews: Kiro, an authentic Japanese restaurant located in Yorkville, offers a diverse menu that stands out for its quality and presentation. Reviewers highly recommend the sushi boat and the aburi pressed sushi for their exceptional flavors. While the menu features premium options such as Wagyu beef and Blue Fin tuna dons, the prices can be on the higher side, especially for lunch specials that aren’t available on weekends. Despite generally positive remarks about the food, many patrons express frustration with the slow and inattentive service, which has been consistently poor across multiple visits. Customers appreciate the cozy, Japan-inspired ambiance that enhances their dining experience, and the large portions add value to their meals. The lunch special bento boxes and the salmon liver plate also receive notable mentions. Overall, while the food earns high praise, the service leaves much to be desired, making Kiro a mixed experience for diners.

formattedAddress: 362 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M5S 1X6, Canada
editorialSummary: Stylish Japanese eatery offering comfy booths, sushi topped love boats & an array of kitchen fare.
reviews: Sushi Maido offers an exceptional dining experience with its fantastic ambiance, featuring separate seating arrangements and great music that enhances the atmosphere. The restaurant prides itself on cleanliness, ensuring that everything from kitchen ware to tables remains spotless. Diners rave about the Bento box, highlighting the quality of the sushi, particularly the well-cooked salmon and delicious rolls that showcase the care put into each dish. The takoyaki also receives high praise, with many noting its fantastic flavor. The service is described as super friendly, contributing to an enjoyable overall experience. Patrons appreciate the reasonable prices for such high-quality sushi, making it a go-to spot, especially for locals. While the rice-to-fish ratio in the sushi could be improved, the fresh fish and excellent flavors more than compensate for it. Overall, Sushi Maido is highly recommended for anyone seeking a delightful meal at brunch or dinner in a great environment.

formattedAddress: 293 King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1J5, Canada
editorialSummary: Sushi bar with a minimalist decor with wood accents serving familiar rolls plus an omakase menu.
reviews: Kinoya offers a dining experience that combines traditional Japanese aesthetics with modern comfort, making it an appealing choice for sushi lovers. The menu features a variety of dishes, including a Sashimi sampler and the Salmon Lover Roll, both of which have received mixed reviews for size and taste. Guests have enjoyed the Sashimi & Sushi dinner as a way to sample different fish, although opinions on authenticity vary, with some finding the flavors lacking compared to authentic Japanese cuisine. The atmosphere is described as dark and quiet, which might not be suitable for everyone, and the service varies, with some staff appearing unfriendly. Despite this, many diners found the food, including sushi and hot dishes, to be generally good, although specific items like the udon and torched aburi salmon were noted as disappointing. While the restaurant has some strong points, such as visually appealing rolls and a pleasant ambiance, several diners expressed reluctance to return due to service issues and inconsistent food quality. Overall, Kinoya may be a suitable option for a casual sushi meal, but expectations should be managed.

formattedAddress: 478 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5V 2B2, Canada
editorialSummary: Snug sushi house with a chill vibe plating Japanese-style seafood specialties & cocktails.
reviews: Saku is a delightful fusion restaurant on Queen West, specializing in Japanese and Mexican cuisine, perfect for brunch or dinner. Diners rave about the happy hour from 9 PM to close, during which they can indulge in an array of specialty dishes. The beef bulgogi, shrimp, kaarage, and the highly praised lobster tacos are must-tries, alongside the mouthwatering birria taco. Sushi lovers will appreciate the Poseidon and Saku specialty rolls, as well as the Saku ceviche, which is beautifully presented. While some found the flavor combinations to be a bit overwhelming or underwhelming, the majority enjoyed the delicious dishes and reasonable prices. The truffle fries received compliments, and the cocktails, such as the blushing dragon and lychee sangria, added to the enjoyable experience. Though the interior decor might need some attention, the lively atmosphere, friendly service, and overall quality of food make Saku a recommended spot for casual dining with friends or a date. Overall, Saku stands out as a vibrant culinary experience worth revisiting.

formattedAddress: 143 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M5G 1C5, Canada
editorialSummary: Vibrant all-you-can-eat Japanese buffet with hot entrees & sushi, plus a diverse take-out menu.
reviews: This restaurant offers an all-you-can-eat (AYCE) dining experience that is highly recommended, especially for dinner with friends. The menu features a great variety of sushi options, including popular choices like the crispy spicy salmon roll, spicy salmon roll, and Philadelphia roll, making it a solid pick for those craving sushi. Many reviews praise the quality relative to the price, particularly highlighting the AYCE lunch special at $21 and dinner at $29.99, though it’s noted that the quality may dip slightly at these lower price points. Diners appreciate the fast and friendly service, although some comments mention occasional rushed experiences during peak times. The BBQ beef ribs are also mentioned as a standout dish. For those looking for takeout, the restaurant provides decent deals, such as five rolls for $22.99. Overall, it's considered an affordable option with a decent sushi selection, making it a great stop for filling meals despite some minor service complaints.

formattedAddress: 486 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M5S 1Y2, Canada
editorialSummary: Casual place with sleek decor offering all-you-can-eat rolls, nigiri & other Japanese favourites.
reviews: New Gen is a hidden gem that promises a wonderful dining experience, particularly for sushi lovers. Diners rave about the exceptionally fresh and flavorful sushi, making dishes like sashimi and various sushi rolls standout choices. The cod has also received high praise as a must-try menu item, showcasing the restaurant's attention to detail and quality. Celebratory dinners at this establishment are complemented by attentive and friendly service, often highlighting the dedication of staff like Christine, who adds a personal touch to the experience. While customers appreciate the large portion sizes and delicious flavors, some mention that the pricing could be a bit higher than expected, given the quantity served. Overall, New Gen has garnered positive reviews for its delightful food and welcoming atmosphere, making it an ideal spot for dinner or a special occasion. Customers express strong intentions to return, demonstrating that this restaurant has captured the hearts and appetites of its patrons.

formattedAddress: 170 Eglinton Ave E, Toronto, ON M4P 1A6, Canada
editorialSummary: Relaxed setting for all-you-can-eat rolls, tempura, noodles & curry dishes, plus lunch deals.
reviews: The restaurant has garnered mixed reviews, with patrons expressing dissatisfaction over tipping practices, citing a mandatory 15% gratuity regardless of service quality. Diners noted that the food was standard but some dishes stood out, such as the torched sushi and shrimp and vegetable tempura, both well-received for their freshness and flavor. However, criticisms centered on portion sizes, particularly the scarcity of shrimp in dishes like the Thai shrimp soup and the fried rice with beef and shrimp. The steak was praised for being tender and flavorful, while the teriyaki was described as rubbery. Unfortunately, not all aspects were positive; reports of rubbery seaweed in sushi raised concerns about the freshness of the meals, leading to a negative dining experience for some. Despite some positive notes on the environment and service, which included pleasant and efficient staff, the overall experience seemed inconsistent. While several diners enjoyed the all-you-can-eat sushi and appreciated the balance of rice in the nigiri and hand rolls, others reported leaving hungry and dissatisfied. Additionally, the dessert options, though limited, included enjoyable selections like mango, red bean, and vanilla ice cream. Overall, while there were some positives, issues with food quality and service consistency led to many diners vowing not to return.

formattedAddress: 80 Blue Jays Way, Toronto, ON M5V 2G3, Canada
editorialSummary: Named after its Michelin-starred chef, this high-end eatery serves creative Japanese cuisine.
reviews: Akira Back is a beautifully decorated restaurant that offers a cozy atmosphere, making it an excellent choice for special occasions like birthday celebrations. The service is attentive and friendly, contributing to a pleasant dining experience. Guests enjoyed a light dinner menu featuring standout dishes such as the highly praised tuna/mushroom pizza ($29) and delicious wagyu tacos ($26), both considered must-tries. The chef’s mystery box also received accolades for its incredible presentation and flavors, alongside well-prepared options like chicken, lamb chops, and sea bass. Diners reported mixed reviews about certain dishes; a cucumber salad was noted as lacking flavor and a corn dish was found to be oily. While some drinks hit the mark, others were less favorable, and the overall experience may be slightly hindered by the restaurant's smaller, noisier space. However, the intriguing desserts and the photogenic ambience make it a memorable venue worth revisiting.

formattedAddress: 2036 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4S 1Z9, Canada
editorialSummary: Japanese staple with spare decor offering an all-you-can-eat buffet plus an à la carte menu.
reviews: Echo Sushi offers a delightful dining experience, particularly for sushi lovers craving fresh and high-quality dishes. Customers have praised the generous fish-to-rice ratio in both their maki and nigiri, recommending the standout Snow Dragon Maki Rolls which are complemented by tobiko and kewpie mayo. The ambiance reflects that of a traditional izakaya, creating a warm and inviting atmosphere, although some diners noted the décor could benefit from improvements. Service has been highlighted as friendly and attentive, with staff taking time to explain every dish. While past experiences have been mixed, with some diners encountering issues with flavor and freshness in takeout orders, the restaurant has overall received commendations for its reasonable prices and consistent quality. Despite some menu naming quirks, the general consensus is that Echo Sushi is among the best options in Toronto for sushi enthusiasts, making it a highly recommended choice for dinner. Overall, patrons express satisfaction with the food, atmosphere, and engaging service, ensuring a positive dining experience.

formattedAddress: 493 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M5S 1Y2, Canada
editorialSummary: Diners can opt for a-la-carte or all-you-can-eat sushi at this casual Japanese restaurant.
reviews: Monkey Sushi is a casual spot frequented for its decent sushi and great value, particularly known for its enormous bento boxes that can easily serve two meals. Reviewers appreciate the quality of the fish and the reasonable pricing compared to other establishments. Notably, the California roll receives positive mentions, while the dragon rolls have been criticized for lacking adequate salmon, leading to a disappointing experience for some diners. Despite the solid food offerings, service seems to be a recurring issue; patrons have noted unfriendly waitstaff and poor attention to dine-in customers, with many essentials needing to be requested multiple times. The atmosphere has been described as messy and chaotic, largely due to the emphasis on takeout orders. While some diners express joy in the comforting flavors of the sushi, others found their experience marred by metallic-tasting tap water and a lack of utensils provided. Overall, Monkey Sushi offers a mix of commendable sushi choices for lunch and dinner but suffers from significant service shortcomings.

formattedAddress: 482 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M5S 1X8, Canada
editorialSummary: Casual eatery offering specialty sushi rolls, teriyaki plates & Korean dishes, plus a small patio.
reviews: Sushi Japan has received mixed reviews, with one customer having a particularly disappointing experience when ordering rolls through Uber Eats. They complained about unmentioned seaweed, stale rolls, and a strong, unpleasant odor that made the meal inedible, ultimately leading to a refund. In contrast, other sushi establishments in Toronto have garnered positive feedback, especially for their fresh and tasty offerings. For instance, a favorite dish is the crispy spicy salmon roll, which is complemented by gyoza and the unique sushi pizza—a fried rice base topped with fresh fish. Customers appreciate large roll sizes and perfectly made tempura, although some have noted that service could be improved, such as the absence of complimentary water. Overall, the dining experience can vary significantly, with recommendations leaning toward visiting places featuring fresh ingredients and generous portions. For those looking for solid sushi, it might be worth exploring options beyond Sushi Japan.

formattedAddress: 2425 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4P 2E7, Canada
editorialSummary: Snug spot with a wide variety of rolls, plus nigiri, sashimi & cooked Japanese dishes.
reviews: At Sushi Rock, diners can enjoy a delightful dinner experience with a variety of fresh and flavorful options. The menu features dishes such as Hakka chow mein, beef on a hot plate, spicy rolls, and a variety of sushi rolls and bento boxes. Many guests have praised the generous portion sizes, especially highlighted by the salmon lover party tray, which showcased super fresh fish and impressively large rolls. The service is noted as efficient and friendly, with multiple staff members ensuring quick delivery of meals. Although some guests did have concerns with online ordering, particularly regarding misleading portion sizes and sticky rice, the overall consensus is positive. The new location of Sushi Rock maintains the high quality of its food while introducing improvements in flavors, particularly with their spicy mayo. For anyone who enjoys Asian cuisine, this restaurant comes highly recommended for its great atmosphere and tasty offerings. Many patrons are eager to return for more of the delicious dishes available.

formattedAddress: 110 Harbour St Unit 108B, Toronto, ON M5J 2L9, Canada
reviews: This restaurant offers a delightful dining experience with a warm atmosphere, perfect for intimate dinners or special occasions like birthdays. Guests rave about the excellent service provided by attentive staff, particularly a server named Fabio, who is knowledgeable and accommodating, making the experience enjoyable for everyone. The menu features an impressive selection of dishes, highlighted by beautifully prepared sushi, including sea bream and a special omakase menu, along with delicious appetizers like crispy Fish Kama and fresh sashimi. Customers appreciate the attention to detail and cleanliness throughout the establishment, contributing to an overall pleasant experience. The prices are considered fair when weighing the quality of the food and service, with dinners averaging around $160 for multiple courses. Reservations are recommended due to its growing popularity, especially on busy evenings. Overall, this restaurant is highly recommended for those looking to enjoy high-quality food and exemplary service in a vibrant setting.

formattedAddress: 414 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5V 2A7, Canada
editorialSummary: Japanese seafood option with a varied menu, adventurous presentations & comfortable decor.
reviews: To-Ne Sushi offers a delightful lunch experience, featuring excellent quality sushi that stands out in Toronto's dining scene. The restaurant is praised for its friendly staff and inviting ambiance, making it a great spot for a quiet meal. Diners have enjoyed dishes like the salmon sushi lunch, assorted sashimi platter, and the spicy udon, which have consistently been described as fresh and delicious. With prices ranging from $14 to $25 per dish, the value for the quality is exceptional, allowing groups to leave feeling satisfied without breaking the bank. Regular guests appreciate the attention to detail in every roll, with the rice-to-ingredient ratio particularly noted for its perfection. The atmosphere is calm and not overly loud, perfect for a relaxed brunch or lunch outing. Overall, To-Ne Sushi is highly recommended for anyone seeking top-notch sushi, with a commitment to quality that has made it a local favorite since 2011.

formattedAddress: 150 York St, Toronto, ON M5H 3S5, Canada
reviews: The dining experience at this Toronto sushi restaurant promises exceptional quality and attentive service, making it a standout choice for special occasions like birthdays. Guests rave about the Omakase experience, highlighting the salmon and fatty tuna as standout dishes. The friendly chefs not only prepare sushi meticulously but are also eager to accommodate preferences, such as adjusting wasabi levels. Although the one-hour seating limit can feel rushed for larger groups, the intimate ambiance and serene atmosphere create a memorable setting. Patrons also enjoy a variety of sake flights, adding to the overall experience. The restaurant is praised for its dedication to high-quality ingredients across all courses, from appetizers to dessert. Many describe it as an educational experience, with chefs explaining the preparation of each dish, enhancing the appreciation for sushi. Overall, it is recommended for those seeking top-tier sushi in a beautifully designed space.

formattedAddress: 80 Dundas St E, Toronto, ON M5B 2P5, Canada
editorialSummary: Classic sushi favourites & other Japanese fare offered up in standard surrounds.
reviews: This restaurant is a favorite for sushi lovers, offering a variety of dishes perfect for a casual lunch or dinner. Frequent patrons often recommend the Salmon Avocado Sushi and the Sushi & Sashimi Set for 2, which provides a fantastic value at around $39. The bento boxes, including the Salmon Sushi/Sashimi and Salmon Teriyaki, are also popular, coming with delicious sides like tempura shrimp, miso soup, and seaweed salad. Customers appreciate the convenience of ordering through a device at the table, although some prefer to order in person to avoid spicy mix-ups. Despite the casual atmosphere, the food is consistently fresh and well-prepared. Regulars enjoy the House Maki and praise the crispy beef gyoza that accompany their larger orders. Overall, the combination of good portions at reasonable prices, alongside favorable online takeout experiences, makes this restaurant a go-to for satisfying sushi cravings.

formattedAddress: 1049 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6H 1M4, Canada
reviews: This quaint sushi spot offers a delightful dining experience for lunch, particularly on quieter days. Diners have reported enjoying flavorful and fresh sushi, with standout options like the Philadelphia roll and inari sushi roll, generously portioned for under $30. The service is consistently praised for its kindness and efficiency, with orders taken and food prepared quickly, allowing guests to savor their meals without long waits. While the atmosphere is described as simple and unassuming, patrons emphasize that the quality of the food easily compensates for any lack of decor. Many customers recommend trying the sashimi, which has also received positive feedback despite some comments on sushi rice not holding well. Overall, the restaurant delivers impressive portion-to-price ratios, making it a popular choice among both regular visitors and newcomers alike. Despite occasional indifferent service, the overall experience continues to attract loyal customers craving great sushi.

formattedAddress: 761 Bay St. Unit 2, Toronto, ON M5G 2R2, Canada
reviews: This restaurant offers an exceptional dining experience with a focus on high-quality sushi and unique ingredients like purple rice. Diners appreciated the freshness of the fish, particularly in dishes like the salmon and avocado rolls, which were part of lunch specials accompanied by miso soup and salad. The cucumber and avocado rolls, along with the dynamite classic roll, were also highlighted for their taste and reasonable pricing. Though a strawberry smoothie was chosen, reviews suggest it might not have been the best fit for a sushi restaurant. Service is consistently praised as friendly and efficient, making guests feel welcomed in a clean and charming atmosphere. However, there were a couple of minor hiccups, such as a Pokebowl that arrived without rice, though the quality of the food remains a strong point, with many diners expressing eagerness to return. Overall, this place is a fantastic choice for a late-night sushi craving or a delightful lunch near Queen’s Park.

formattedAddress: 675 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4Y 1T1, Canada
reviews: This restaurant offers a fantastic tasting box for two, featuring a delightful variety of flavors and textures, making it ideal for dinner. However, it primarily focuses on take-out, with limited seating and a wait time of about 25 minutes if dining in. The poke is praised for its balanced portions and well-seasoned rice, although some reviews mention that the price could be more competitive compared to other poke spots. Sushi is a highlight here, noted for its freshness and reasonable pricing, but some dishes, like the tuna burrito, have suffered from quality issues due to poorly cleaned fish. The dining experience leans heavily towards convenience, with takeout packaging that can create a disjointed atmosphere for diners. Even though the establishment has a beautiful ambiance, it's more suitable for quick meals than casual hangouts. Overall, if you're looking for quality sushi and poke for a lunch or dinner takeaway, this spot is worth a visit, just be aware of the caveats regarding seating and wait times.

formattedAddress: 376 Eglinton Ave W, Toronto, ON M5N 1A2, Canada
editorialSummary: Relaxed Japanese eatery offering a variety of sushi, plus bento boxes & teriyaki at lunch & dinner.
reviews: Nikko Sushi is a charming restaurant praised for its high-quality sushi, particularly the House Sashimi combination, which consistently receives positive feedback. Diners appreciate the good fish-to-rice ratio in the sushi rolls, although some reviews point out that the six-piece rolls sometimes contain only six pieces, which may lead to confusion for takeout orders. While the overall atmosphere is deemed cozy and inviting, the service can be notably slow, even during less busy times, leading to frustrating experiences for some patrons, especially with dishes like the bento box. Diners have expressed disappointment over the quality of certain items, such as the salmon, which was reported as small and burnt, and the chicken, described as dry. The tempura vegetables were criticized for being oily, and the miso soup was served cold. Despite these drawbacks, many customers love returning for the fresh and tasty offerings and some commend the vegetarian options and alternate rice choices. Those in search of a pleasant sushi experience may find Nikko Sushi a worthwhile destination, though it's clear that there are inconsistencies in food quality and service.

formattedAddress: 33 St Joseph St, Toronto, ON M4Y 1J8, Canada
editorialSummary: Easygoing option, one of a local chain, known for choice sushi, plus Korean & Japanese cooking.
reviews: Tokyo Sushi at Saint Joseph offers an authentic dining experience, characterized by knowledgeable staff, a charming atmosphere, and quick service. Patrons rave about the freshness and quality of the sushi, including delightful options like the Kakimaze don and generous servings of salmon don, which are praised for their perfect fish-to-rice ratios. Diners appreciate the friendly service, with the owner even surprising families with complimentary desserts, enhancing the overall experience. This hidden gem is an excellent choice for both lunch and dinner, particularly for seafood lovers. Customers note the spacious layout and outdoor seating, making it a nice escape from the bustling streets nearby. With reasonable prices and attentive service, many recommend Tokyo Sushi as a must-visit for anyone in the area. Overall, it's a fantastic spot for those seeking high-quality sushi in a welcoming environment.

formattedAddress: 750 King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1N3, Canada
editorialSummary: This low-key Japanese eatery serves traditional fare, with combination specials at lunch.
reviews: Ichiban Sushi is a charming, family-owned restaurant that captures diners' hearts with its warm atmosphere and friendly service. Guests rave about the delicious sushi offerings, such as the Red Dragon Roll, Sunshine Roll, and Toronto Roll, which are noted for their impressive size and balanced flavors. The meal begins with complimentary fried dumplings and a rich miso soup, setting a delightful tone for the dining experience. Many reviewers highlight the exceptional hospitality, with owners going out of their way to ensure a memorable visit and encouraging patrons to take their time. While some diners have expressed mixed feelings about the overall sushi quality, the general consensus leans towards satisfactory food served in a welcoming environment. Customers appreciate the affordable prices and the personal touch of service, making it a favored spot for families, including those with children. Ichiban Sushi proves to be more than just a meal; it's a place where guests feel valued and appreciated, prompting many to pledge their return. Overall, the combination of friendly staff, tasty dishes, and a cozy atmosphere makes Ichiban Sushi a standout choice for a delightful dining experience.

formattedAddress: 120 Atlantic Ave, Toronto, ON M6K 1X9, Canada
reviews: This restaurant has garnered positive reviews for its delicious and generously portioned dishes, making it a great spot for lunch or dinner. Diners have enjoyed the Chicken Katsu Bento Box, which features extremely crispy chicken, flavorful noodles, and tasty gyoza, all for a reasonable price. The sushi offerings, including the salmon bowl and green dragon roll, are noted for their quality and ample size, although some diners would prefer smaller, longer rolls to accommodate easier eating. The cozy atmosphere and fast service add to the overall appeal, making it a hidden gem in Liberty Village. Many patrons appreciate the great value for money, especially with the bowls that can be easily shared. The Miso Soup is also highlighted as a comforting choice on colder days. Guests recommend supporting the local business and express eagerness to return, with intentions of trying different dishes on their next visit.

formattedAddress: 626 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M6J 1E4, Canada
reviews: Aria is a sushi restaurant located in the Queen West area that offers a range of typical sushi dishes with reasonably priced options. Diners have enjoyed items like the Aria combo, which includes a spicy salmon roll, salmon sushi, and avocado salmon roll, served with soup and salad for a modest price of $28. While the sushi is generally considered decent, some reviews indicate that it lacks distinctiveness compared to other sushi establishments. Customers appreciate the friendly service, although some have noted that the staff can be slightly inattentive at times. For those seeking gluten-free options, Aria is accommodating, offering dishes like gluten-free dynamite rolls and shrimp tempura. The pricing is also favorable with a 10% discount for cash payments. However, some patrons have found the quality of the fish and the texture of the rolls to be average, suggesting that while it's a solid choice for a casual meal, it might not meet the high expectations set by previous reviews. Overall, Aria is recommended for anyone in the area craving sushi but without the need for an extravagant experience.

formattedAddress: 1560 Yonge St Unit #118, Toronto, ON M4T 2S9, Canada
editorialSummary: A menu of sushi, bento boxes, rice dishes & more in a contemporary Japanese restaurant.
reviews: Sushi Gen is a charming Japanese restaurant renowned for its fresh and comforting sushi, making it a perfect spot for lunch or dinner. Patrons rave about their favorites, including the sashimi platters, Spicy Tuna Roll, and the standout Dragon Roll, all delivering a delightful balance of flavors. The Chicken Teriyaki dinner is another highlight, featuring grilled teriyaki chicken served with rice, salad, and miso soup, while the separate packaging of the teriyaki sauce helps keep the chicken crispy during transportation. Diners also enjoy the Dynamite Rolls, noting the ideal ratio of filling to rice that allows for a more enjoyable eating experience. Alongside the exceptional food, the restaurant boasts a clean and inviting atmosphere, complemented by friendly and attentive service. Seasonal specials keep the menu fresh and exciting, appealing to both sushi enthusiasts and newcomers alike. With consistently positive experiences, Sushi Gen stands out as a local gem that provides a delightful dining experience, both in-house and through delivery. Highly recommended for anyone in the area looking for delicious Japanese cuisine.

formattedAddress: 559 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M5S 1Y6, Canada
editorialSummary: Relentlessly festive Japanese tapas hot spot with a strong sake selection & woody interior.
reviews: This restaurant offers a vibrant atmosphere and an impressive selection of Japanese cuisine, making it an excellent choice for dinner or a fun night out. Diners rave about dishes like the salmon carpaccio and beef carpaccio, highlighting their freshness and flavor. The Kinka Set is particularly popular, providing a satisfying array of delicious options, including nigiri and fried chicken. Families are welcomed warmly, with attentive staff eager to assist, especially when introducing children to sushi; the sea bream sashimi is a great choice for little ones. Guests also enjoy the refreshing Neko drinks, which add a fun touch to the dining experience. The desserts, including yogurt sorbet, round off the meal perfectly. Overall, this restaurant is praised for its share plates, great vibes, and excellent service, making it a delightful culinary destination.

formattedAddress: 10 Bay St. #105, Toronto, ON M5J 2R8, Canada
editorialSummary: Flame-seared sushi is the specialty at this Japanese fine-dining destination with soaring ceilings.
reviews: Miku is an elegant and romantic Japanese restaurant in Harbour Front, perfect for dinner, especially for couples celebrating special occasions. While the atmosphere is sophisticated, some diners found it a bit lacking in vibrancy. Guests rave about the delicious food, including standout dishes like oysters and the chef's combo, which showcases a variety of sushi. Despite the high price tag, with meals averaging around $250-300 including drink pairings, many felt the quality justified the cost, particularly noting the fantastic green tea opera cake for dessert. Service received high marks for staff knowledge and attentiveness, with waiters providing detailed explanations of each dish. However, some patrons felt that the flavors, while decent, did not fully meet the high expectations set by the restaurant's reputation. Overall, Miku delivers an enjoyable dining experience with beautifully presented dishes, making it a noteworthy choice for Japanese cuisine lovers.

formattedAddress: 2352 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4P 2E6, Canada
reviews: Nestled in midtown, CoCo is a sushi shop known for its value but has been critiqued for its limited menu and average quality offerings. Diners have tried various dishes such as Maki, tempura shrimps, and the classic salmon lover set, alongside the white dragon roll featuring butterfish. While some enjoyed a buy one get one hand roll deal, others felt the sushi lacked sufficient fish, leaving them wanting more for their money. Conversely, Senryo has received high praise for its fresh tuna and salmon sashimi, admired for its creamy texture and generous thickness. Their party tray, featuring a selection of rolls like California and sweet potato, offers great value and ample food, making it ideal for gatherings. Although cleanliness concerns were noted in some reviews, the overall sentiment leans towards a recommendation for those seeking reasonably priced sushi. Despite varying experiences, the emphasis on freshness seems to unite both establishments, particularly at Senryo, which stands out for its quality.

formattedAddress: 171 E Liberty St #146, Toronto, ON M6K 3P6, Canada
reviews: Kibo Sushi in Liberty Village is a fantastic dining spot, particularly known for its delicious and high-quality sushi offerings. Guests have praised the freshness and presentation of the sushi, making it a go-to place for sushi lovers. The restaurant features a gamified menu that adds a refreshing touch to the dining experience, and the portions are generous, providing great value for the price. The Yuzu Sangria is a must-try drink that complements the meal perfectly. While the atmosphere is described as somewhat bare, the attentive and friendly staff enhance the overall experience. Diners appreciate the quick service, especially on hot summer days, as the cool AC is a notable advantage. While there are many local pubs in the area, Kibo is highly recommended for those specifically craving sushi. Overall, patrons rate their experience highly, often stating it as a 10/10 due to the scrumptious food and professional service.

formattedAddress: 513 Mt Pleasant Rd, Toronto, ON M4S 2M4, Canada
editorialSummary: Vibrant, informal 2-floor eatery offering a menu of popular Japanese dishes, plus lunch specials.
reviews: Sushi Supreme is a beloved restaurant that has maintained its reputation for quality food despite relocating. Regular patrons rave about their delicious miso soup, udon, sushi, salad rolls, and hot plate dinners, highlighting the extensive menu that offers a variety of options. Diners appreciate the affordability and value of the dishes, making it an excellent choice for both casual meals and special occasions, such as parties with combos and party trays. The friendly staff enhances the dining experience, ensuring that customers feel welcome and well taken care of. Although the new Mount Pleasant location is cozier and has fewer tables than their previous spot on Yonge, the food quality remains impressively consistent. Regulars enjoy standout items like Sushi Gold and Salmon tempura, alongside refreshing drinks like their signature tea. The restaurant’s convenient location, just a 15-minute walk from the Davisville TTC subway station, adds to its appeal as a go-to spot for sushi lovers. Overall, it's a superb option for anyone looking for reasonably priced, high-quality sushi and a friendly atmosphere.

formattedAddress: 1384 Bathurst St, Toronto, ON M5R 3J1, Canada
reviews: Kiyo offers a delightful dining experience marked by its charming decor and friendly service, making it a must-visit spot in the area. Guests rave about the creative sushi plates, particularly the visually impressive Maki rolls and the fresh-tasting Spider Roll, both of which deliver a wonderful explosion of flavors. For dinner, diners have enjoyed generous portions, including the Kyoto and Fuji dishes. The restaurant's unique cat-themed decorations add a playful touch, and many patrons appreciate thoughtful details like pre-cooled beverage glasses. However, there have been complaints regarding the restaurant's temperature, with some patrons finding it uncomfortably hot, impacting the freshness of dishes like Chirashi don. Despite this, most reviews highlight the excellent service and overall enjoyable atmosphere, making it a favorite among sushi lovers. While some experiences may vary, the restaurant's commitment to quality food and customer care stands out.

formattedAddress: 122 Elizabeth St, Toronto, ON M5G 1P5, Canada
editorialSummary: Cozy, Japanese nook attracting lunch crowds with, sushi, butterfish sashimi & heaping noodle dishes.
reviews: This restaurant offers a mixed experience, especially for sushi lovers. Previously known for its varied and beautifully presented Omakase, recent visits have reported a decline in quality and consistency, particularly with the tailored offerings for dietary restrictions. Diners have noted that the deluxe chirashi and Sushi & Maki platter provide decent quality and generous portions, but do not quite live up to expectations, especially after being victim to increased prices and smaller portions compared to the past. While the takeout experience has room for improvement, the food is still praised for its freshness, particularly the fish. The ambiance is described as super tiny and cramped, leading many to prefer takeout instead of dining in. Starters like the Japango platter, featuring gyoza, agedashi tofu, and various rolls, received positive feedback, especially regarding the gyoza's crispiness. Although there are bright spots like enjoyable rice and certain rolls, the restaurant might not be the go-to for Omakase enthusiasts as it once was. Overall, while it remains a decent option for lunch or dinner, it seems best to manage expectations based on the recent trends in quality and service.

formattedAddress: 36 Charlotte St #102, Toronto, ON M5V 3P7, Canada
reviews: This acclaimed takeout sushi spot in Downtown Toronto is a hidden gem that locals rave about. The restaurant, located on Charlotte St but tucked around the corner, offers a quick service for walk-in and online orders. A standout dish is the Aburi Scallop Dragon, complemented by Spicy Scallop Rolls, Kamikaze, and Salmon Sashimi, all for an amazing price. Customers frequently commend the Maki Platter B, noting that it provides ample portions for two, including a delightful fried roll that stands out as a favorite. The takoyaki and Snow Dragon rolls have also received praise for their flavor and filling portions. With neat packaging and consistently good taste, the restaurant delivers an excellent sushi experience at affordable prices. Whether celebrating a small achievement or simply indulging in sushi, patrons leave satisfied, making it a highly recommended destination for sushi lovers.

formattedAddress: 373 Eglinton Ave W, Toronto, ON M5N 1A3, Canada
editorialSummary: Japanese favourites like creative sushi rolls, noodles & bento boxes offered in a warm, comfy space.
reviews: Tokyo Sushi is a highly regarded restaurant known for its delicious and fresh offerings that cater to sushi lovers. Diners frequently praise the extensive sashimi options and specialty rolls, including their recommended cucumber salad rolls, which feature salmon, mushrooms, avocado, and crabmeat wrapped in cucumber without rice. The restaurant serves a variety of meals throughout the day, making it an ideal spot for lunch, dinner, or special occasions. With a $28 meal that can easily feed two people, guests often enjoy generous portions of sashimi, dragon rolls, and sushi, along with complimentary appetizers that enhance the dining experience. The consistent quality, presentation, and exceptional service have earned Tokyo Sushi a loyal customer base, despite some wishes for extended weekend hours. While some reviewers suggest there's always room for improvement, the overall sentiment is that the food and service are top-notch, making it a dependable choice for both dine-in and takeout options. Easy street parking adds to the convenience, attracting repeat visitors who appreciate both affordability and quality.

formattedAddress: 1992 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4S 1Z6, Canada
reviews: Zone is a charming and affordable Japanese eatery located just two blocks from the Eglinton subway station, making it a convenient choice for a quick meal. Despite its small size and limited menu, it offers quality options like rice, miso, and a variety of sushi dishes, all at reasonable prices. The Dragon Lovers Party Tray, featuring 42 pieces of sushi for $40, is particularly notable and generously serves multiple diners. Guests have mentioned the freshness and flavor of the hand rolls, which come filled with thick pieces of sashimi. However, not every dish has hit the mark, with some commenting on the dryness of the deep-fried gyoza. The friendly and attentive service adds to the experience, with complimentary items like seaweed salad and spring rolls enhancing the meal. While the venue does face accessibility challenges due to stairs and a lack of automatic doors, the overall value and quality of the food make it a hidden gem for brunch or lunch in Toronto.

formattedAddress: 1612 Bayview Ave, Toronto, ON M4G 3B7, Canada
editorialSummary: A range of sushi & sashimi offered with teriyakis & noodles, plus lunch specials, in a quaint space.
reviews: The restaurant is a highly recommended gem in Leaside, known for its exceptional food quality and service. Diners rave about dishes like the steaming hot edamame with fresh sea salt and the delicious black dragon roll. Specialty items, such as the Kinmedai sashimi and soup, are pre-order favorites, while the Eglington roll and rich smoked salmon are also highlights. Frequent visitors appreciate the restaurant's consistency over the years, offering a variety of options from simple steak teriyaki to elegant omakase selections. The cozy atmosphere, complemented by two patios, makes it a perfect spot for a dinner date or a casual meal. Newcomers can enjoy generous portions, as noted by a first-time guest who tried the fried chicken udon and salmon avocado hand roll. Overall, the restaurant caters to both avid Japanese food lovers and those looking for a comforting meal, proving that the price doesn’t reflect the quality offered.

formattedAddress: 643a Mt Pleasant Rd, Toronto, ON M4S 2M9, Canada
reviews: Yukashi offers a remarkable dining experience, particularly noted for its omakase, which showcases beautifully presented and delicious food. Diners have praised the incredible dishes, emphasizing their freshness and intricate presentation, making the meals both visually appealing and satisfying. The chef, Izutsu, engages warmly with guests, contributing to a fun and memorable atmosphere, especially highlighted during anniversary dinners. While the food and sake pairings are described as impeccable, some customers mentioned delays in service, with only one server managing the dining room, which occasionally led to longer wait times and needed more detailed explanations of the dishes. Still, the overall sentiment is overwhelmingly positive, with many looking forward to returning for the seasonal menu changes. This memorable dining experience at Yukashi, paired with the chef's engaging personality, certainly merits high praise and a Michelin star-worthy reputation.

formattedAddress: 275 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M5T 1G1, Canada
editorialSummary: Casual standby offering creative sushi rolls & other Japanese fare in simple environs.
reviews: This restaurant offers a cozy, mom-and-pop atmosphere with friendly service and quick food delivery, making it an ideal spot for both casual dining and special meals. Their All-You-Can-Eat (AYCE) sushi is highly praised, particularly the spicy salmon sushi, which boasts a fresh taste with a nice kick. For dinner, the small sushi platter is recommended as it offers great value, while the grilled squid and sashimi appetizers provide a delicious start to the meal, with the sashimi noted for its thick, fresh cuts. Bento boxes are another highlight, with excellent pricing and generous portions that leave customers satisfied. Although the Chicken Teriyaki rolls could use a bit more tenderness, they still deliver good value at a reasonable price. Overall, the combination of great food, welcoming owners, and a relaxed ambiance makes this restaurant a must-visit whenever in town. Whether you're in for a hearty dinner or a sushi craving, the menu items are sure to impress.

formattedAddress: 530 Eglinton Ave W, Toronto, ON M5N 1B4, Canada
reviews: Hay Sushi is a beloved spot for sushi enthusiasts in Toronto, renowned for its mouth-watering selection and cozy ambiance. Many diners rave about the authentic Japanese cuisine, particularly recommending the Tendon for its perfect crunch. While the in-house dining experience is generally enjoyable with friendly service, some customers have encountered disappointing takeout orders, noting issues with small portion sizes and inaccuracies in their sushi selections. A recent $270 takeout order revealed that the donburi bowls came with minimal meat, and the miso soups were only half full, leading to dissatisfaction compared to the dining-in experience, which tends to offer larger portions. Despite these hiccups, the quality of the sushi, including vegetarian options like tofu and shrimp tacos, has garnered positive feedback. Overall, while Hay Sushi offers delightful dishes such as sushi rolls and hearty brunch options, the inconsistency in takeout service may make some patrons hesitant to return. Nevertheless, it remains a comfort spot for many sushi lovers in the city.

formattedAddress: 701 St Clair Ave W, Toronto, ON M6C 1B2, Canada
editorialSummary: Relaxed, brick-walled Japanese eatery serving traditional fare such as sushi & noodle dishes.
reviews: Kibo offers a diverse selection of sushi and Japanese-inspired dishes, making it an appealing choice for those seeking a casual dining experience. Diners have praised the overall atmosphere and friendly staff, highlighting the restaurant as a good spot for sushi lovers. Customers enjoyed the two-person meal set featuring various appetizers and sushi rolls, although some noted that the quality of the side dishes was not up to par. The chicken Karaage received mixed reviews; while it was tasty, some diners felt it leaned more towards Korean flavors than authentic Japanese. The chicken yaki udon also faced criticism for not matching expected Japanese flavor profiles. Additionally, a Bento box ordered by a guest fell short of expectations, lacking in portion size and variety. Interestingly, patrons can benefit from a 10% discount for cash payments, but some diners experienced confusion regarding pricing and portion sizes for items like the Weston Maki. Despite its inconsistencies, Kibo remains a popular choice for fresh sushi in Toronto.

formattedAddress: 48 St Clair Ave E, Toronto, ON M4T 1M9, Canada
reviews: The restaurant offers a variety of dishes, with notable mentions including the sashimi Bento box, which comes well-packaged and includes a generous portion of fresh fish, hot miso soup, and tempura that is fried to perfection. Patrons commend the sushi for its quality, particularly highlighting the fresh avocados in the California roll, as well as the excellent salad dressings. The dining experience is generally pleasant, with friendly staff who provide good service for both dining in and takeout. However, some reviews report a stark contrast in experiences, with a few diners experiencing poor quality sushi and sashimi, citing issues such as thick cuts of fish and unappetizing wonton soup. A particularly alarming review mentions finding hair in the sushi, leading to unsatisfactory customer service when seeking a resolution. Despite the mixed feedback, many agree that this establishment is a better option than grocery store sushi, especially if you prioritize supporting a local business. Overall, the emphasis on freshness, generous portions, and attentive service are frequent highlights, making it a place worth trying for sushi enthusiasts looking for lunch or dinner options.

formattedAddress: 550 Queens Quay W #11, Toronto, ON M5V 3M8, Canada
editorialSummary: Sashimi & clever sushi rolls, plus Japanese kitchen entrees, served in a cool, wood-accented space.
reviews: This restaurant, located by the lake, offers both dine-in and takeout options, though experiences vary widely among patrons. Guests have praised its quick service and the ability to customize dishes, particularly enjoying the Aburi Rolls. However, several diners have expressed concerns regarding the freshness and preparation of the food. The Iruka Udon was found lacking in variety, while the Salmon Lover Combo was criticized for its smaller-than-average pieces of fish, with some sushi and sashimi being thicker and chunkier than ideal. Though prices are fair, expectations for quality preparation seem unmet, suggesting that the restaurant’s appeal may rely heavily on its tourist location. Several reviews mention issues with service, including slow responses and an apparent lack of attentiveness from staff. Overall, while the restaurant hits the spot if you're craving sushi, diners have noted that they would appreciate improvements in quality and service.

formattedAddress: 342 Adelaide St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1R7, Canada
editorialSummary: A menu featuring Japanese & Mexican flavors in a modern, railroad-style space with exposed brick.
reviews: This tiny downtown restaurant offers a unique fusion of Mexican and Japanese cuisine, making it an excellent choice for both sushi and taco lovers. Popular dishes include the bulgogi tacos, fried lobster rolls, spicy salmon rolls, and the highly recommended Baja fish tacos, which are praised for their quality and flavor. While the sushi portions are generous and the seasoned chicken impresses diners, some guests have noted that certain dishes can feel small for their price. The menu features a variety of appetizers, including gyozas and Japanese croquettes, all of which have received positive feedback. Although the restaurant does not accept reservations and can be quite busy, wait times are generally reasonable, and the service is attentive and efficient. Most meals, featuring a couple of appetizers along with sushi and tacos for two, usually average around $40 per person. Overall, this restaurant is highly recommended for a casual meal, whether dining in or ordering takeout, thanks to its flavorful offerings and inviting atmosphere.

formattedAddress: 331 Spadina Ave., Toronto, ON M5T 2E9, Canada
editorialSummary: An all-you-can-eat menu of dim sum & sushi, plus teppanyaki & udon dishes, in a casual setting.
reviews: This restaurant offers an exceptional dining experience with a focus on high-quality all-you-can-eat sushi, particularly lauded for its thick salmon sashimi and delectable dim sum. Guests have praised the generous portion sizes and the thoughtful service, highlighting staff members like Chris and Connie for their attentiveness and friendliness. The ambiance is complemented by aesthetically pleasing dishes that are delicious and well-prepared. However, some diners noted issues with service speed, especially during the 90-minute lunch limit that made it feel rushed. While the extensive menu provides a variety of options, the lunch selection felt somewhat limited for some customers. The desserts, including the mango pudding and ice cream, received positive mentions for their quality and presentation. Cleanliness is a strong point, with tidy dining areas and restrooms, which enhances overall confidence in the establishment. Just a reminder for visitors: be cautious of portion control, as failing to finish your meal could incur extra charges. Overall, this restaurant comes highly recommended for both the food and the service.

formattedAddress: 285 College St, Toronto, ON M5T 1S2, Canada
editorialSummary: Counter-serve eatery for sushi-stuffed burritos & other seafood dishes such as poke bowls & tacos.
reviews: The restaurant offers a variety of sushi dishes, with customers particularly enjoying the Maki combo, which consists of 16 pieces of sushi and is affordable at approximately $12. While some reviews praise the freshness of the ingredients and the decent quality of the sushi, others express concerns about the customer service, noting a rude interaction with the female staff member when inquiring about sauce options. Additionally, hygiene issues raised by diners regard a male staff member's repeated sneezing without a mask, creating discomfort for those with health concerns. Despite these negative experiences, many patrons appreciate the convenient location, especially for students near the University of Toronto. The Sushi Burrito is also a popular item, with variations like the Raising Sun with Tuna being highlighted. Customers find the restaurant clean, with organized packaging for takeout, and enjoy the overall healthy offerings. Still, some reviews label the food as "mid," suggesting that while it has its merits, it may not meet everyone's expectations for quality or value.

formattedAddress: 533 Parliament St, Toronto, ON M4X 1P3, Canada
editorialSummary: Chandeliers adorn this cozy Japanese eatery serving traditional fare such as sushi & noodle dishes.
reviews: Kibo offers a delightful dining experience for sushi lovers, particularly for those seeking fresh and flavorful dishes. The restaurant's Salmon Lover's menu stands out for its rich, buttery salmon paired with perfectly seasoned rice, making it a must-try. Customers highly recommend various sushi options, including the Spicy Salmon, Spicy Tuna, and Green Dragon, along with beautifully crafted maki rolls such as the spicy salmon cream cheese roll. For those looking for a quick meal, the takeout service is efficient, often seeing patrons return multiple times a week. While the tempura may not impress everyone due to its heavier batter, overall feedback highlights the freshness of the fish and the reasonable pricing. Additionally, the inclusion of miso soup and salad with some menu items adds an extra layer of satisfaction. The restaurant’s charming packaging and friendly staff further enhance the dining experience. Overall, Kibo is a great spot for a satisfying sushi dinner or lunch.

formattedAddress: 12 Queens Quay W, Toronto, ON M5J 2R9, Canada
editorialSummary: Tiny spot for sushi with a no-frills vibe, offering sushi bar seating & curtained booths.
reviews: This cozy, family-run Japanese restaurant offers a unique dining experience with individual booths for privacy. The ambiance, while quaint, is somewhat overshadowed by cleanliness issues and a few minor service hiccups, such as slow water refills. Among the dishes, patrons enjoyed the spicy California roll and the dynamite roll, noting the freshness of the ingredients, while some rolls like the rainbow and green dragon fell short on taste. Vegetarians may find options limited, though the server is accommodating in helping to customize meals, such as swapping meat for tempura yam in sushi. Miso soup and fresh green salad complement the sushi offerings well, and the tempura is praised for its perfect batter. While some reviews express disappointment with the overall specialness of the experience, others appreciate the affordability and hidden charm of the restaurant. Feedback is mixed regarding whether diners would return, but many highlight the excellent food quality as a redeeming feature. Overall, this spot seems to attract a loyal clientele despite minor flaws.

formattedAddress: 124 Atlantic Ave, Toronto, ON M6K 1X9, Canada
editorialSummary: This petite place prepares familiar Japanese dishes such as tempura & teriyaki, plus rolls & nigiri.
reviews: This sushi restaurant offers a delightful dining experience that leaves guests thoroughly satisfied. The freshness of the ingredients is evident in every dish, especially the SS1, which includes an impressive variety of 7 sashimi and 7 sushi pieces. For those opting for a heartier meal, the dinner bento boxes and salmon bento are generous and flavorful. While one customer mentioned a little too much onion in their Chicken Don Buri, overall feedback highlights the attentive service and cozy atmosphere. Many have praised the unique taste of the wasabi, distinguishing it from store-bought varieties. The lunch bento specials, often with extra rolls, have also received high marks for their deliciousness and fulfilling portions. Guests appreciate the kindness of the staff, who even provide complimentary treats like candy and Pocky to enhance their dining experience. With reasonable prices and excellent quality, this sushi spot has quickly become a favorite for many.

formattedAddress: 672 St Clair Ave W #2, Toronto, ON M6C 1B1, Canada
reviews: Goen Japanese Restaurant is a standout venue for anyone seeking authentic Japanese cuisine at reasonable prices. The warm and inviting atmosphere complements a menu full of classic dishes, including sushi, sashimi, tempura, and teriyaki, all crafted with fresh ingredients. Customers rave about the delicious salmon sushi combo, featuring melt-in-your-mouth salmon alongside perfectly cooked rice, as well as the great value offered, with meals averaging around $22 per person. The presentation of each dish is impressive, and the generous portions enhance the dining experience. The restaurant's prompt service and attentive staff consistently contribute to a memorable outing, making it ideal for solo diners, couples, or groups. Notably, the maki rolls boast great rice-to-filling ratios, and the crab rangoon is a hit among patrons. However, some diners expressed disappointment regarding the lack of veggies in the tempura rainbow roll. Overall, Goen is highly recommended for its superb quality of food, service, and ambiance—definitely a must-visit for Japanese food lovers in the area.

formattedAddress: 281 Augusta Ave, Toronto, ON M5T 2M1, Canada
reviews: This restaurant offers a delightful experience, especially for sushi enthusiasts. The salmon pocket sushi and takoyaki are particular highlights, with the latter being praised for its perfect crispiness and savory flavor. Guests have been impressed with the range of sushi options available, including the recommended Omakase meal that showcases an assortment of Inari style sushi, each with unique and rich flavors. The atmosphere is calm and inviting, complemented by friendly and attentive staff who go out of their way to ensure a memorable visit. Many patrons have mentioned their repeats, enjoying dishes like cheesy crab, salmon aburi, and unagi stamina. The presentation of thefood, along with the aesthetic of the restaurant, adds to the overall dining experience. For those looking for quality sushi in Toronto, the restaurant in Kensington comes highly recommended, making it a must-visit for brunch or dinner.

formattedAddress: 345 Bloor St E, Toronto, ON M4X 1L7, Canada
editorialSummary: Modest Japanese hideaway turning out a wide variety of sushi rolls, sashimi & lunch specials.
reviews: Kibo Sushi House offers a serene and welcoming atmosphere, making it an ideal spot for a relaxing lunch or dinner. Patrons rave about the incredible freshness of the sushi, particularly the Kibo Signature and Aburi Scallop Dragon Rolls, both of which have received high praise for their flavor and quality. The tempura, lauded for its perfect crispness, complements the sushi offerings beautifully. Diners appreciate the quick and friendly service provided by the knowledgeable staff, enhancing the overall dining experience. The restaurant's small size makes it a great choice for takeout, especially given the busy neighborhood filled with sushi options. Many customers have declared Kibo as their favorite sushi spot, frequently returning for both the ambiance and delicious food. Overall, this restaurant successfully combines fresh, mouth-watering dishes with attentive service, making it a standout in the local dining scene.

formattedAddress: 76 Gerrard St E, Toronto, ON M5G 2A7, Canada
editorialSummary: Elegant, compact Japanese restaurant offering chef's-choice menus of traditional sushi or tempura.
reviews: This sushi restaurant offers both omakase and tempura omakase, providing a unique dining experience for lunch and dinner. The lunch omakase, priced at $55, consists of 10 courses featuring fresh seafood with highlights like scallop and sea bream, although there are mixed opinions on some fish types being average. Diners appreciate the delicious and perfectly seasoned rice, alongside a simple yet authentic menu that lacks experimental flavors. The tempura omakase, a rare find in Toronto, has received rave reviews for its expertly fried seafood, praised for being tender inside and crispy outside without the greasiness. The ambiance is described as clean and relaxing, with friendly staff who are accommodating to dietary restrictions. Many patrons enjoyed the sake tasting, especially the yuzu variant, and noted the impressive freshness of the fish, free from any unpleasant odors. Overall, the restaurant has been labeled a hidden gem perfect for special occasions, providing an unforgettable experience for sushi lovers.

formattedAddress: 836 College St, Toronto, ON M6H 1A2, Canada
reviews: This restaurant offers a range of sushi and sashimi, which reviewers noted as being fresh and not fishy, a common complaint at other sushi spots. Popular items include the Love Boat for two, featuring soup, salad, and tempura, and the standout salmon don paired with delicious tempura. The ambiance is described as cute with uplifting music, making it a great date spot, although it tends to get busy around 6 pm with online orders. While some customers praise certain dishes like the squid kaarage and dynamite rolls, others experienced inconsistencies in quality, mentioning an overload of rice in maki rolls and poorly prepared sushi that resembles mall sushi. One diner particularly criticized a bento box meal for its clumpy teriyaki sauce and lack of flavor, claiming to have wasted half their food. Despite mixed reviews, the specialty ice cream, including free mochi for positive reviews, remains a highlight. Overall, this restaurant has potential but seems to struggle with maintaining consistent quality across its offerings.

formattedAddress: 2584 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4P 2J3, Canada
editorialSummary: Sushi, sashimi & imaginative Japanese dishes served in stylish, bright environs.
reviews: Rollian Sushi has garnered rave reviews for its incredible presentation and fresh, delicious dishes, making it a top choice for sushi lovers. Diners have enjoyed a variety of rolls, including the medium boat, smoked paradise cucumber roll, black dragon roll, and golden dragon roll, all praised for their quality and the generous rice-to-fish ratio. The shrimp tempura appetizer and miso soup served as delightful starters, while the salmon everything sushi combo provided a satisfying main course. The restaurant's ambiance is described as cozy and clean, perfect for a casual meal or takeout. Patrons commend the warm and friendly service, with staff being accommodating and patient, even during busy times. Whether for lunch or dinner, guests consistently highlight the freshness of the ingredients and the skillful preparation. With repeat visitors and new customers alike expressing their appreciation, Rollian Sushi stands out as a must-visit destination for anyone craving high-quality sushi. Overall, this place impresses with its commitment to excellence in both food and service.

formattedAddress: 600 Mt Pleasant Rd, Toronto, ON M4S 2M8, Canada
reviews: Shibui is a quaint and cozy restaurant that offers an exceptional dining experience centered around sushi. Celebrating a birthday here resulted in an unforgettable meal, highlighted by the amazing premium nigiri, which is strongly recommended for those willing to indulge a bit more. The restaurant is praised for its fresh and delicious sushi, with a diverse menu that caters to various tastes, making it suitable for lunch and dinner. The chirashi bowl stands out as a must-try dish, appreciated for its quality and presentation. Diners have noted the fast and friendly service, which enhances the overall atmosphere. However, some customers felt that particular dishes, like the Maki role, could be a texture concern. The restaurant maintains cleanliness and a warm ambiance, contributing to a memorable experience. With a great selection of Sake and attentive staff, Shibui is a neighborhood gem for sushi lovers.

formattedAddress: 55 Adelaide St E, Toronto, ON M5C 1K6, Canada
editorialSummary: Kimono-clad servers in a traditional spot with a sushi bar, Robata grill & tabletop hot pots.
reviews: This Japanese restaurant excels in providing a top-notch dining experience, particularly for sushi and sashimi lovers. Reviewers rave about the freshness and quality of the ingredients, with highlights including the exceptional black cod and well-executed sushi rolls. For those seeking a cozy and intimate atmosphere, the restaurant's traditional yet elegant decor adds to the overall charm. The service is generally commended for being attentive and friendly, contributing to the positive dining experience. However, some guests noted inconsistencies, especially with the seasonal Winterlicious menu, where dishes like small oysters, bland poached fish, and dry wagyu steak fell short of expectations. Despite the mixed reviews on certain menu offerings, the shrimp tempura and the Yakuza ice cream received high praise. Although the prices are on the higher side, many patrons believe the quality of the food justifies the cost. Overall, this establishment is highly recommended for dinner or special occasions, particularly for its sushi and sashimi selections.

formattedAddress: 181 Bay St., Toronto, ON M5J 2T3, Canada
editorialSummary: A sleek space with contemporary Japanese dishes & sushi designed for sharing, plus a buzzy bar area.
reviews: Ki Modern Japanese Restaurant in Toronto offers a mix of standout dishes and letdowns, creating a varied dining experience. While the restaurant has garnered praise for its fresh sashimi and sushi, some guests have encountered service issues, like mistakes with orders and lengthy waits for attention. Popular menu items include the Wagyu burgers, noted for their juicy flavor, and the tempura tiger shrimp served with a delicious wasabi aioli. For lunch, the Bara Chirashi Bowl paired with a refreshing Sunomono Salad has received positive feedback, particularly among business diners. Additionally, the restaurant's ambience caters well to both solo diners and larger groups. Despite some customers feeling that food prices don't align with the quality, the cocktails and staff attentiveness add to the overall appeal. The mix of traditional and modern influences can lead to a gratifying meal, though the dining experience may vary depending on the day. Overall, Ki Modern Japanese remains a recommended spot for Japanese cuisine enthusiasts looking for a vibrant atmosphere and diverse menu options.

formattedAddress: 171 E Liberty St Unit 144, Toronto, ON M6K 3P6, Canada
editorialSummary: Stylish, contemporary restaurant adorned with portraits furnishing cocktails & Thai specialties.
reviews: This restaurant offers a delightful dining experience with a variety of satisfying dishes. Despite occasional waits, such as a half-hour for food, reviewers agree that the meals are well worth it, particularly the delicious green curry rice and the impressive meat portions. Diners enjoyed flavorful options such as Panang curry, mango salad, Thai shrimp rolls, Tom Yum soup, and Islamic noodles, which were highlighted as standout items. The restaurant is known for its tasty desserts, including the tempting black forest cake and rich cheesecake, although some diners felt portions have decreased in size. The atmosphere is described as lovely and peaceful, complemented by attentive service from staff, such as the dedicated server Tao. Large groups are accommodated graciously, even near closing time, ensuring everyone has a fulfilling experience. Overall, this restaurant has earned high recommendations for its delicious food and exceptional service, making for memorable dining occasions.

formattedAddress: 651 College St, Toronto, ON M6G 1B7, Canada
editorialSummary: Cozy restaurant specializing in familiar Thai curry, rice & noodle dishes, plus desserts.
reviews: This restaurant offers a mixed experience with its Thai cuisine, as highlighted by various reviews. Many diners praised the Tom Yum soup for its excellent flavor and a pleasant spice that wasn't overwhelming, while others enjoyed the Chicken Khao Soi, noting its flavorfulness and satisfying portions. The Chicken Wings were also commended for their seasoning. However, there was a stark contrast in experiences, as one customer had a deeply negative encounter with the "famous Pad Thai," which was described as unhygienic and oily, leading to feelings of sickness. The Pad See Ew with beef was similarly criticized for its stale texture and low-quality ingredients. While some appreciated the restaurant's atmosphere and service, including a kind waitress, others found it difficult to overlook the hygiene issues and bad quality of certain dishes. Overall, while some items like the Chicken Khao Soi and Tom Yum hit the mark, there are significant concerns regarding food safety and consistency that potential patrons should consider.

formattedAddress: 370 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M5B 1S5, Canada
editorialSummary: Modest Thai option with wood-paneled booths serving spicy curries, noodles & other classic eats.
reviews: This Thai restaurant offers a nostalgic dining experience reminiscent of beachside eateries in Thailand, complete with lovely seating and a view of Yonge Street. The atmosphere is inviting, making it a good choice for an unplanned visit. The menu features a variety of dishes, appealing to different tastes, with highlights including the Chicken Fried Rice, beef Pad See Ew, and chicken wings, which are highly recommended. The service is noted for being quick and attentive, enhancing the overall experience. However, there are mixed reviews regarding the authenticity of the food; some diners found the curry and spring rolls lacking in flavor and size, specifically mentioning the watered-down curry that missed the mark on traditional taste. Despite this critique, many enjoyed the value and speed of service. Overall, it appears to be a decent option for a casual meal, especially for those looking for halal chicken.

formattedAddress: 35 Baldwin St, Toronto, ON M5T 1L1, Canada
editorialSummary: Warm, unfussy option serving classic Thai standards from rice to noodles plus a lunch special.
reviews: Koh Lipe offers a bustling dining experience with authentic Thai cuisine, where reservations are recommended due to its popularity. Guests enjoy a quick service but should be prepared for a 90-minute dining limit, which can make meals feel rushed. The menu features a variety of dishes including Islamic noodles, which are highly praised for their flavorful red curry gravy, and Pad Thai, a classic that consistently delights diners. Other highlights include the giant portions of fried crispy pork, pineapple fried rice, and a seafood curry. However, some dishes, such as the Pad See Ew, received mixed reviews for being overly salty, detracting from their flavorful potential. While the food presentation is visually appealing, it’s worth noting that the spice levels can catch diners off-guard, so caution is advised for those sensitive to heat. The atmosphere is cozy but small, adding intimacy to the dining experience, and there are gluten-free options available as well. Overall, Koh Lipe is well-suited for those who appreciate authentic Thai flavors, particularly as a spot for date nights or casual dinners.

formattedAddress: 669 King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1M9, Canada
reviews: Wang Lang on King Street delivers an exceptional Thai dining experience, renowned for its flavorful and beautifully presented dishes. Diners rave about the Yum Salmon, a fresh and zesty spicy salmon salad that tantalizes the taste buds, as well as the mango sticky rice, a delightful dessert blending sweet mango with creamy coconut rice. Popular menu items include the classic Pad Thai and the Pork Pad See Ew, both praised for their superb flavor and perfect noodle-to-meat-to-veg ratios. Patrons appreciate the warm, inviting ambiance, making it a great spot for anything from casual lunches to special celebrations, with good atmosphere especially noted on busy weekend nights. The restaurant is well-regarded for accommodating various needs, with attentive service ensuring a satisfying experience. Many claim the flavors transport them to Thailand, citing it as superior to other local Thai establishments. Wang Lang also offers great lunch deals with slightly smaller portions, allowing for a diverse tasting experience. Seasonal items enhance the extensive menu, making each visit exciting, and those who pay in cash can enjoy additional discounts. Overall, Wang Lang is a favorite for many, holding a consistent reputation for authentic Thai flavors and impressive customer care.

formattedAddress: 252 Carlton St., Toronto, ON M5A 2L3, Canada
reviews: This Thai restaurant has garnered a lot of attention from patrons who appreciate its flavorful dishes and vibrant atmosphere. Many diners rave about the crispy pork noodles, stating they are tender and soft, while others enjoy the spicy and tangy pork bone soup, and the soft shell crab fried rice. A standout favorite is the Khao Soi, which is praised for its wonderful flavor and texture. Guests often visit for lunch or dinner and have noted that portion sizes are generous, leaving them satisfied. However, some reviewers mentioned minor inconveniences like slow water service during busy hours and mixed experiences with server friendliness. While many found the experience delightful, one group was disappointed with the lack of flavor in their Tom Yum soup and clams, although the crispy pork belly was a highlight. Overall, this spot is popular enough to have customers waiting in line, and cravings for their comfort food are common.
